text: Wonderful! Everything is great. I wish I lived next door. The bread is the best. Pan Pizza's are so delicious.

Delicious pastries and super nice workers. Everything here is a great choice from pizza to bread to all kinds of pastries. Cash only and they totally work with to get you the most for whatever bills you might have.
Hands down best Meatball sub in Chicago. Way better than Bari because they make their own bread and the meatballs are Nonna's recipe

Cash only. So bring some to snap up the goodness in this place. Cookies? Yep. Freshly baked bread? Yep Freshly baked and sesame-dipped breadsticks that are crunchy beyond belief? Yep Fresh pan pizza topped with a wide array of ingredients? Yep Sub sandwiches ranging from vegetable to meatball in three different sizes nestled between the freshly baked bread? Yep Reasonable prices? Absolutely! Parking is not easy. And there is usually a line, but it moves quickly. Just bring cash. And enjoy!

Absolutely a gem.   It is easy to find a bakery for  deserts but not so for breads, let alone good breads.  Love their breads!  Bought two crusty sourdough 1-pounders, Italian ice and cannolis.  Will try other goodies next time.  Found free parking easily on side streets 10am Sunday.

We ordered the cannoli, tiramisu, and a blueberry bar. The cannoli was one of the best I have ever had. The tiramisu and blueberry bar were also delicious. I am very much looking forward to coming back here soon.

After traipsing around trying and failing to find an ATM, I bought an amount that aligned with what I had in my wallet. Specifically, I got a sfogliatelle and, instead of a sandwich, a tomato focaccia. The sfogiatelle was tasty but not my favorite: the outside wasn't as crisp as it should have been, and the inside filling seemed more like pudding than like ricotta. The focaccia caught me off guard with how tasty it was, though. It was a full pizza substitute: the bread was thick, flavorful, and oily, and it was balanced very nicely by the tomato topping. I'd try the breads if I were in the area again.

By far the best Italian/French bakery in Chicago.  Family owned and operated since opening day.  Knowing the family and how genuine they truly are has made the experience special each visit.  Delicious food is always consistent making the meal unparalleled.  Just had a chocolate cannoli yesterday after the D'amatos combo (a must) and it was amazing! Keep it up y'all!!
If you live near this place and never been, i feel sorry for your mother. Heck, even if you like 200 miles away, you need to get some cannoli from this place. P____ off the chain wax.

Hands down, one of the best bakeries in Chicago. Always fresh, always authentic, you can't go wrong. I've yet to go there when it's been empty and there's a good reason for it. Their breads, sandwiches and especially the sheets of pizza bread (which is perfect for parties FYI) are drool-worthy. Just don't go there on an empty stomach because the delicious smells and eye popping food displays will destroy you. Also, cash only! But they have an ATM on the side of the building.
Good food/family owned. If it wasn't cash only I would come here a lot more often.

Chocolate covered cannoli..mmmm.  What more do you need to say.  Always a great special dessert.  Usually we drop by and my wife picks up the cannoli while I pick up sandwiches at Bari next door....great traditional Italian food.

Ordered a large cannoli for my daughter's communion & was told it'd be $55, filled with 30 small cannolis(see pics). Upon picking up my order, I noticed they had regular cannolis for $1 each. I began to wonder what size the small cannolis would be. They showed me the top & asked if I was satisfied I said yes, the presentation was great. Took it home, only to realize the small cannolis were very tiny. They covered both ends of the large cannoli with 15 tiny ones on each end & the middle was empty, very disappointing. Especially since the size of the $1 cannolis were much larger. I felt ripped off. I could've just purchased 55 regular cannolis for the same price & would've been satisfied. Now I know for next time, beware! On the hand, their bread & pizza looked delicious , will definitely have to try next time. That iz all...

One of us ran to Bacci next-door for a delicious sub to go.  I ran into D'Amatos for the bakery.  I ordered a slice of pizza to go. It was a specialty pizza that had olives and artichokes...it was amazing.  I ordered something we have never had before called an Arancini which is some sort of rice ball with ground beef and pea's and they put spaghetti sauce on it. We got a huge loaf of fresh baked bread and 3 specialty pastries; napoleon. Eclair & something else.  The entire order was $20. The food was phenomenally fresh.  With everything that we bought (including Back's sub) it was either lunch or dinner and we ate the rest of it the next day too.  It was really incredible. I am accustomed to going to excellent bakeries but they charge six dollars per pastry. I do not know what they charge but we got a ton of food for $20. Just make sure you bring cash they do not accept debit cards.  For less than $10 you could have your main course a specialty dessert and for less than five dollars you could just have your lunch without the desert. Excellent place, home-baked food....we'll be back!
Best pizza and subs too go Great cannoli and macaroons too Always fresh and good family business

I would stand in line to get a piece of their bread. It is one of the best in Chicago. But there are other excellent Italian bakeries in Chicago also. There are also other places that have a large selection of cookies also. I am driving by and I see a sign in the window. Pepper and egg sandwiches. I get one with cheese and I am one my way with a loaf of happiness in my car. Unfortunately I didn't know I had paicked up a imposter. For those who don't know what a real pepper and egg should really be this is the furthest thing from it. The best ones have a flat scrambled egg with actual long pieces of pepper and a SLICE OF CHEESE. In a real place they are going to make the eggs to order, which would would be a flat egg. That also keeps it from falling out of the sub. This what I got: premade scrambled eggs with so much salt on them I am still drinking water 6 hours later. Grilled onions. Who the f... puts onions on a pepper and egg sandwich? And where were the peppers? There were 4 peanut sized peices of pepper. I guess there was a cheese shortage because there a couple pieces of GRATED cheese on my sub. THE WORST EVER!!! Please I beg of you take the pepper and egg sign down before you ruin another persons day or get someone in the kitchen who knows a pepper and egg is not a onion and egg sandwich. Fero's Hungry Hound in Bridgeport still makes a real one for those who know the difference. I guess the moral of the story is don't sell stuff you don't know anything about and dont't go to a bakery for a sandwich. J.P Graziano on Randolph is excellent for those who need the real.

Coming from Rhode Island, I NEEDED to find an authentic Italian bakery. Thankfully, I came across D'amato's on Yelp and WOW am I glad I did! First off, this place is oozing with Italian culture. Their selection includes (but is certainly not limited to) freshly baked bread, pizza by the slice, cannolis, sfogliatelle, zeppole etc. I wish I could live here and eat one of everything for every meal. The staff is loud, quick and very friendly. It's cash only so don't forget your moola! I can't wait to come back for more deliciousness. Thank you for saving me D'amato's!

It's a shame that Subway sandwiches exist when there are places like this. THESE sandwiches are what subs should taste like. Swoon! I ordered a 10" veggie and it came out and the bread was crisp and the veggies were amazing! No bell peppers and some stringy lettuce here! It was artichoke hearts and fresh mozzarella! And it was cheaper than subway! What? Go here and eat a sub, you will thank me later. Delicious! Best I've ever had!
Love! Reminds me of Grandmas kitchen. Cannoli to die for! Be careful when offering a large pizza, it will feed 50 people ;)

I liked this place even before they offered Sandwiches and made Bari Irrelevant. Their Pizza is one of my favorites and they have nice people working there. No Clusterf*cked confusion  when you order there, unlike next door. Highly recommended.
the best pizza & bread in chicago hands down!  omg  incredible. family tradition for years. live this place.

I'm not sure why I am writing a review for D'amato's. I'd rather others don't find out about this gem, 'cause the lines are long. This place has the best bread in the city. They make it in house using a coal oven. The bread is crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside. Additionally, they supply the bread to many restaurants in the city, so you probably have tasted their awesome bread.  Moving on, you have pizza by the slice. They'll heat it for you in a few minutes, and you are ready to go. If you wanna be a real piggy, eat a slice here, and take the other one home. Once you are home, pop it in the oven for about 10-15 min., and this thing will blow your mind.  When you finish eating, don't forget about the cookies and pastries you just picked up. Enjoy your GIANT canolli, or your gelato (or both). I won't judge.  It's cash only, so come prepared.
The pizza here is delicious. A great option is to get a full pizza to take home and heat up in the oven. An affordable way to feed a crowd. Also the cannolis are legit.

Neighborhood classic, been coming here for years. I stopped in after driving by looking for a place on a saturday after a meeting. Thought why not. Had an Italian sandwich it was delicious. I tomatobread is amazing. I've had a lot of the bakery items over the years, I cant remember to name them all, too lazy to look it up and not going to guess on the spelling. But it's good! Trust me! Writing this review, I kinda want to go back now. Not right now but this weekend

Excellent service and delicious bakery eats. Cash only though, which is an inconvenience. Luckily I had some cash or otherwise I would have circled for parking a million times and take out my toddler out the car in the cold for a big disappointment.  Delicious sweets! :)

I was in need of cannolis for our family's "Godfather" movie night dinner. I found this diamond of a bakery on yelp and decided to give it a go based on their Yelp cannoli reviews. Everything looked amazing and the staff was friendly and made the buying experience fun.  I did not note that they take only cash...but their is an ATM machine right outside so I was able to adjust easily. A customer who bought cookies told me that every single one was delicious. She was buying two boxes worth. As for the cannolis, I was NOT disappointed.  Delicious! Crispy on the outside and creamy sweet ricotta goodness on the inside with some tiny chocolate chips surprises in bites.  The pistachio garnish added a delicious and distinct crunchy accompaniment to the treat! While I was there, I picked up two loaves of bread for the dinner.  Again, a WINNER!  the bread was crispy on the outside and soft white home goodness on the inside. The texture was excellent. I did not realize how complacent I had become with other Italian/French breads that were rife with large pockets of air baked into their loaves. No more!  I am a fan of D'amato's Bakery!  My final words... "take the cannolis!"

Words can really describe this jewel.  Friendly staff, great baked goods.  Do yourself a favor and get here and try anything.  Try some cookies, or the pizzas or the baguettes..... oh the baguettes....  just get the long, yes it's 3 feet long, but you'll eat half of it on the way home.  Definitely a place to go out of your way for.

One of my two favorite Italian bakeries in the city.  I called and asked if they had a half sheet of tiramisu.  The confirmed that they did and I rushed right over.  The place was packed but the ladies behind the counter greeted every customer with the same cheerful smile.  The price was very reasonable at $35.  Unfortunately, they only accept cash. The next day we celebrated my friend's birthday and the cake was an instant hit.  At least five people asked where I purchased it and I told them D'amato's on Grand Ave.  It would be great if this place expanded to include tables and chairs.  If they did, I would definitely stay for a cappuccino with my baked good.
I love d'amatos so much. Amazing cookies for coffee, CANNOLIS TO DIE FOR. Everyone working is always very kind! Def worth a stop if you are in the area.
We have moved to Texas but when we are back in Chicago (never enough). Our favorite bakery. Does anyone know if they ship?

I haven't been here in a while, but I always mean to go back. I'm a lazy commuter though, so -shrug-.   The pastries are awesome. I've had the lobster tail, a raspberry one of the same name, the cannoli's and a few other puff-pastry + creme combos. I have yet to find an italian bakery that I like more than I like this place. The pastries are never stale or soggy - the pastry is fluffy and crisp, and the fillings are never too sweet. The cannoli was perfectly crunchy. Not a moment of stale-ness could be detected. If I remember correctly, it's cash-only. There isn't anywhere to sit inside though, so grab a box to go.  The service wasn't great. A bit unfriendly. But this was several years ago and it honestly doesn't stop me from wanting to go back as soon as I can remember to when I'm in that side of town.

This is my favorite place for bread in Illinois. Been coming here for 30 years. The charcoal ovens lend great flavor! The pizza (breadlike thick crust) is also a big hit with customers. Be careful, though, about the sweet stuff. I bought a chocolate eclair this weekend that was so stale it was unpleasant to eat.

Love this bakery! The pizza here is delicious beyond words. It's more like gooey pizza bread. I bought two full sheets of the cheese pizza for a party, and everyone was obsessed. For the amount of pizza you get, it's beyond affordable. I also have to mention that I always enjoy the staff that run this place. They are so nice and friendly and always accommodating. The cannoli's are also amazing. I have all my coworkers hooked on them. It's cash only, so come prepared!

I cannot believe this is my first time here! I had the meat arancini with red sauce (they asked me if I wanted it and I figured, why not? They know what's best) for breakfast (they warmed it up) - this must be the best breakfast deal around!! At 2.75 the arancini, who can want more?? I bought the taralli to try later (someone commented how good they were). They looked great, multiple options (regular, pepper. Garlic) available. For lunch picked up an italian sandwich on foccacia bread, coz it sounded soo good! You get an entire huge foccacia sliced in half and filled with all the good italian meats (mortadella. Capicollo, salame) and other toppings. She asked: giardiniera too? Of course I had to try it (the hot!). At 8.50 the sandwich which is enough for 2 hungry people, this must be another amazing option for great tasting affordable food in this town! Tried a regular cannolo too (since I was there...) '- nice and crunchy shell, smooth ricotta inside, a pretty good cannolo overall. They have many sandwich options, all appear to be really good deals for what you get. Highly recommend! They sell many different kinds of very authentic appearing Italian cookies.
Most incredible pizza bread, light sauce was perfect.  I ordered Mushrooms.. just perfect.  Italian sub with sweet peppers to an added sweetness perfect incredible crispy italiano bread!

This popped up on Yelp asking me if I wanted to review it.  How did Yelp know this is my favorite bread, pizza and Italian cookie place!  This bakery is a throw back to a much simpler time.  They bake everything in their own facilities (which are across the street).  The bread is perfectly crusty.  They bake daily and when it's gone, it's gone.  The cookies are fantastic too.  They remind me of the bakery around the corner when I was 6.  I love their pizza and sandwiches too.

Best Pizza Bread I've had. It's like a delicacy to me. Big, squared off pieces of focaccia that I've piled up with sauteed onions, garlic, peppers, sausage, and a little extra marinara make my home creations a work of art. The bread is doughy and flavorful, and has a nice surface for holding lots of toppings. I've never had such before this but I love it. A friend works not far away and brought some home, now I'm hooked!  I know I'm gonna go back for a sandwich there some time. Delicious!

D'Amatos is a family owned business that has been a west town and chicago area staple for YEARS! If you want bread that is made fresh daily (they always look like they are working hteir butts off) and has no preservatives this is the best you can find!! I have never been disappointed by their quality and the bread is always hard to put down.  You can tell that true Italian love and passion go into this business. HIGHLy recommend
Crunchy cannoli shell with perfectly smooth and sweetened ricotta--for $2 and with friendly service you can't beat it!

Situated adjacent to Bari's grocery and amazing meatball sub sandwich, Damato's Bakery delivers delicious Italian fare. I had the corner slice of "Sicilian pizza" which I downed in less than a minute. The dough was so soft and tasty. I plan on going back to Damato's for many more treats soon!

Best bread in Illinois, maybe the US and I lived in Europe for 14 years. This is the real deal and the baked goods are just as good. I have only looked at the pizza and watched the sandwiches fly out the door. I can only imagine how good they are. I stop in fairly regularly and see the same faces and new ones all the time. One thing to note which I could care less about, it is all cash!

This place is close by my old office. The first time I tried it was when it was catered in for a coworker's wedding party at the office. We had the most deliciously moist cake ever!!! I then walked by it on the way to a friend's and stopped in for $4 tomato and olive focaccia bread loaf!!!! So yummy!! I wish it was closer to my home!

If you want the real deal Italian experience you gotta stop here!  My buddy who's lived in Chicago his whole life brought me here for my first real taste of chi-town!  The beef sandwich was amazing and the baked goods were even better! This is a must stop for first timers in the city.

This is the bar that any, even the new gluten free whole wheat with all natural seeds bread palace, has to come close too. Bread stacked on one side pizza and cookies and pan apple slices. Real photos on the wall of people that founded the place 70years ago not photos picked by a decorator. Great staff, you better know what you want there's a line already behind you. This place is a treasure, it's real and it works and passes the time test. I hope the young group that is moving into the neighborhood appreciates this wonderful place.

Went to D'amato after reading all the good reviews but I got extremely disappointed from the taste of cannoli. I am not an expert but when I looked up for traditional recipe for cannoli it shows that ricotta cheese should be used for filling, unfortunately I did not get any ricotta cheese taste in their cannoli. They have used crushed peanuts with food coloring to make it look like pistachios. When I thought of buying bread saw one of their employees or managers walked in through the door checked all the baguette in the kitchen by touching those with her bare hand then she proceeded to dealing with customers cash at the counter. At that point I have decided not to buy the bread and walked out of the store. Needless to say I will look for cannoli & bread elsewhere.
Excellent small Carryout  for sandwiches and snacks... You can buy really fresh cookies by the pound with mid and match

D'Amato is a tiny Italian bakery in Chicago's River West area that features Italian baked goods, bread, pizza and Italian Ice. We swung by here after lunch at Coalfire Pizza for some dessert. We ordered a cannoli, some chocolate cake, some Italian cookies and a slice of pepperoni pizza (1" deep dish pan pizza). They had a large selection of cookies and a few other baked goods. The cannoli and cookies were very good and I highly recommend. The pizza was nothing exciting (Little Caesars is better!), and the Chocolate Cake was dry; not worth the calories. The fresh baked bread looked amazing but we didn't try it. Based on what we had, this place is a 3 1/2. The prices were fair too. Also, If you plan on swinging by here don't expect to sit and relax. This is a grab and go type of place. They have a bar at the window with 3 stools.

What a great spot, I love old school Italian places like this they remind me of my childhood growing up in Berwyn homemade Italian cookies, cannoli's, and a pizza that will blow your mind, it's soooo tasty they don't put a lot of cheese on it which I love because we all know too much cheese makes us sorry later, only saw 2 kinds here sausage and pepperoni, they come by the sheet, half whole or slice, I bought a whole sheet last week and it looked like I ordered it from Fred Flinstone HUGE, great thing about the pizza is not only is it delicious it's even better when you warm it up in the oven at home, I've also had the Italian sub from here and it's probably one of the best I've ever had capicola, salami, ham, the works, to top it off the sub was enormous, next time I come I'm getting the bakery you could tell everything is homemade they have a warehouse across the street where they make and do everything thing, this is not a sit down place so come in order and take it home, great place to order food and dessert if your having a party, saw a cannoli cake concoction on the wall it was gigantic hope I have an excuse one day to order it, can't wait to try more things from this place.

I was visiting Chicago and had the good fortune to see a D'amato's Bakery delivery van driving down the street I was on. Given that I love a good Italian Bakery, I decided to make the trek to see how this one stacked up. My trek was well worth it, as the food from this small bakery is fantastic. I got several varieties of cookies, and each was better than the last. Since I was leaving the city the day after I bought the cookies, I wasn't able to eat them until I returned home, but they still were fantastic - I can only imagine how good they would have been the same day! As for the staff, they were incredibly helpful and patient as I picked out all my sugary treats, and the storefront itself - while small - was fun to walk around in and look at all the baked goods. My only regret was that I wasn't hungry enough to try some of their sandwiches or pizzas (next time I'll just get one and eat it anyway!).

Love D'amatos! I have been coming here since high school. $3-4 for a slice that will fill you up! The slices are pretty greasy, but they are so yummy. Will def leave you with cravings.  I am obsessed with the artichoke and olive slice but last time I came they were all gone :(. Hopefully you guys still offer that combo it's my favorite! :)  Also, cute patio outside to sit in.  Try joes tea too! It's amazing you'll love it.

Stopped in here on my way out of Chicago, sniff...It's been a long search for a great bakery in Chicago, after one of my favorites had gone downhill. D'amato's Italian Bakery seemed to be the bakery I've been waiting for!! They have an array of baked goods, as well as pizza! Their pizza came in 3 different kinds.....cheese, pepperoni, and sausage. I got a slice of the pepperoni, which had an old-school square cut, and a homemade taste that was divine!! They also had a great selection of cannoli's and I had to have one.The pizza was a nice surprise, but the cannoli's was the reason why we visited anyways. I had one of their pistachio cannoli's...OH MY!!! So delicious, creamy, crispy shell, and just how it should be!! The pistachios were aromatic with nuttiness, and then with a dusting of powdered sugar, YUM!!!!  Let me add, that not only was the food delicious, but the inside of the store had a fun, old timey feel to it, as if they left it how it used to be, but just kept up with the repairs of the shop! I loved it!!  I can't wait to go back to try their sandwiches, gelato, and so much more!! My mouth is drooling just thinking about it!!  If you are in the Chicago area....you MUST stop my D'amato's on West Grand Ave.!! You will find a little piece of sweet and savory heaven inside!!!
Italian cookies are sooo good, pizza slices are delicious, I came in twice within one weekend! Friendly staff as well, no credit cards..CASH ONLY!

I love this place. I've been going for as long as I can remember as it's a family tradition. My mother grew up in the old neighborhood so it's always nice to stop in at D'amatos when we're back in the area. Great Italian ice, cannoli, focaccia, pizza, subs and cookies! Love that they still use the old cash register too. Only wish they would accept debit/credit and tell some of their newer employees how to provide very basic customer service. All in all, I always consider it a treat to go back to D'amatos!

I know this place makes good bread,  I mean my favorite deli (JPG) uses this bread for their sandwiches, so it must mean something.  The bakery here is phenomenal,  lots of choices and the bread is just amazing.  The sandwiches are also delicious but this review is about my experience today.  I tried their tomato basil soup and it was by far the best tomato basil soup I have ever had.  I got it as part of the half sandwich/half soup special and my wife got her own sandwich.  I literally had to make some serious moves to block access from my wife as she was trying to eat all my soup! We could not stop talking about how good it was.   Don't forget to get the cannoli here,  they are amazing as well!

This bakery is amazing. Have been going here since I was a young kid. My family lived in the north subs but made it a tradition to come here once a month. We would buy their pizza by the sheet pan.  Now as an adult, I go here all the time, sometimes too much for my waistline.  Favorite items are as follows: cheese or pepperoni pizza, cookies(mainly the chocolate ones), veggie sandwich.  The prices are very nice on your wallet. They are cash only!!!  Must check them out!!

This place is love. If you love yourself you will get here and order something you crave because its all so tasty. If you love a friend you can order a made to go sammie on fresh baked bread to share with your bff on an impromptu picnic on a street curb. If you love your mailmanperson for not judging you with the amount of brown paper wrapped packages that vibrate or make strange noises and still delivers safely to your possession, hook them up with the cannoli or the cookies or the pizza or the gelato..its all good. The people here are the nicest. The parking is not so bad if you come off hours. The belly you get after you over indulge is not so much love. but c'est la vie.

This place is so horrible !!! The daughter that runs it (Rosanna) is ignorant and has a shitty attitude and treats her employees like shit ... The cookies are not made there as they say they are bullshit they are made from an Italian bakery on Harlem Avenue and then delivered to them ... They never use gloves to to make the pizza and they also don't have the old school Coal oven to make the pizza like they say it's been gone for years it's a regular gas oven so they got you all fooled !!!! All they do is lie ....

This awesome west loop(ish) bakery has so much good to offer to the world. The ladies behind the counter are truly a blast, the bakery has an incredible history - serving delicious Italian baked goods for over 50 years and they now serve subs?? YES! My favorite ting on the menu is the classic Italian sandwich on focaccia bread!!! Yoooo dried tomatoes and olive oil focaccia bread, split in half with all your favorite Italian toppings. It's literally HUGE and big enough for 4 people to share I kid you not. It's under 10 bucks and has to be one of Chicago's best kept secrets.  Amen. Ohhhhh and they're cash only - so come prepared because their ATM never works.

Everything here is really good, and cheap. Super fresh. Also, every counter girl here is hot. Whoever their hiring manager is has the right idea. So do you like hot girls? and good food? I do. So eat here.

Stopped in for some treats for the kids. First time there. We were very excited by the cookie selection. Narrowed down the cookies we wanted to 2 varieties and inquired about nuts in cookies. Counter lady said only nuts were pecans in the cookies next to our selections, but that there were no nuts in our cookies. Great! We eat pecans by the handful...so a little pecan exposure not a concern at all. First day, kids eat the all-chocolate cookies. Delish, rich little things. No nuts. Next day they eat a vanilla looking cookie with chocolate on top. Yum. Then, uh oh, dear daughter starts reacting like she does to non-pecan/almond/walnut-NUTS.  So I take a bite...peanut looking nuts...baked into the cookie. Administered allergy meds, kid expels ALL food in her system. Then we broke them all open to make sure that the one cookie she ate wasn't just a bakery-oops before writing this review. Nuts baked into them all. Nice bakery for little treat if no food allergies! But food allergy folks beware.

I really love this place they have great subs and the pizza is one of my favorites in the city. One of the things I enjoy about the sub is the bread I think it make the sub. The cookie a dare to say are better than my grand mothers . The staff is awesome always polite and quick. This is a must.
No nonsense sandwich and pastry shop. Very friendly staff and a new, clean store that is reminiscent of old world deli shops.  Went for a quick bite and had to stay for dessert - it was delicious.

This place has a great feel when you walk in. Makes you feel like they've been in business for 100 yrs. When I asked what flavor their cannoli was she ran to the back to get me a sample! It was actually a very sweet plain ricotta filling with chocolate chips. Green dyed peanuts on the ends. A little sweet for me but very nice place. Wish I had ordered a pizza.
Rude employees I had to walk out they lost my business for good!!! If your gonna be ignorant to a paying customer you don't deserve business!!

The bakery goods are wonderful! Really top notch!  But try there Sicilian pizza! It's not your regular everyday pizza.  It's more like a bread pizza but don't let that throw you off. This stuff is the bomb! Mouth watering flavor with a great texture that will keep you coming back for more!  And don't forget to get a couple cannoli's on the way out!  Yum!

I love Italian bakeries like this for 3 reasons: 1. They operate on the "Get in. What do you want? How many? Give me your money and leave" model.  2. Their product is legit. My grandma is from Florence (Yeah, I'm that guy that ITALY DROPS HIS GRANDMA) and everything here tastes just like her recipes. 3. Macaroons.  Seriously man, it's a really great bakery and won't break the bank. If you have issues with their service, grow up and be an adult. If you have issues with their product then you are not to be trusted.

I adore this place for its charm, location, and fabulous food. Whenever we're in Chicago, we always stop by D'amato's for a sandwich and pastries. There's just something about this place that keeps us coming back, whether it's the food, the atmosphere, or the friendly service. We've had their Italian beef (superb) and their meatball sub (wow!), along with a variety of their fresh bakery items. Their cookies and cannolis are fabulous, and I love the wide selection of pretty, decorated cookies in their bakery case. D'amato's also has an outdoor patio, which makes it a perfect place to stop by for a meatball sub on a beautiful sunny fall afternoon.

Amazing! My grandmother who is in her mid 80s and former resident of this neighborhood makes the trek from the western burbs to get bread from this place. Food is still delicious as is the history. Thank you for not changing.

Went for cookies and cannoli and this Italian girl was not disappointed.  Drove 2 1/2 hours to go there and it was worth it!!!  Nothing like it around where I live.  Just like I remember Dad getting when I was young.  Totally surprised I only one of 3 when I walked in but the line was almost out the door by the time I ordered.  Busy place...which speaks for the business.  Good service too.   I highly recommend going to D'amatos!!  ***remember that it is CASH only (but there is an ATM if you need it).

Dare I say this the best pan pizza in Chicago? Prove me wrong, Yelpers. I love that I can walk into this casual bakery and pick up fresh bread, sandwiches and pastries.  Note that this place is cash only and there aren't places to sit. Pick up some focaccia bread and a slice of pizza on your way out. You will not regret it.

Sure the cookies, pizza and everything in this place is good. My problem here is they handle cash only and they pick the bread with bare hands. I don't get it. Is it too much to use a paper or something? Specially after handling cash. I questioned them, and they said they are always using hand sanitizer after getting payments. Nah. Not convinced.  I think it's very disrespectful. If they are doing this in front of the customer's face, imagine what they are doing in the kitchen. Ewww.
Great bread, meatball sub is where it's at and the tomato soup is incredible. New favorite spot!
Best pizza I ever had. I love how the sauce has a wine taste to it. And the pastries are very fresh. This is a CASH ONLY bakery but it's worth it! Yum yum yum

Its not easy finding a loaf of crusty Italian-style bread outside of Italy, but  probably the closest thing to Pane di Genzano ( crusty on the outside and soft on the inside ) that you will find in Chicago is made at D'Amato's,  And the sesame breadsticks , "forget about it". You can't just eat one.  Their bread is available at select grocery stores, but I always head down to Grand Ave.  Their focaccia, tomato breads, and pizza-like slices are the best.  While I'm totally devoted to the subs next door at Bari,  the sandwiches here are a close second.
Amazingly tasty and super affordable. We split a giant Italian Focaccia sandwich, 2 cannoli, and two sodas all under $20. Highly recommend! Cash only but there is an ATM attached to the building.
Great tasting food at good prices.  They don't take credit cards so bring cash.  .. really really good tomato spinach pizza. Yummmm

Stopped in to check out some cannolis as a friend of mine was thinking of purchasing several hundred for a wedding. We both agreed amazing and that these cannolis are it! Just as we wrap things up we encountered a rude girl/lady giving us an attitude about where we can eat. She made her own assumption and didn't think we were paying customers, we all know when you make an assumption you look like an ass! Sadly we were in the process of going back in to inquire about a major order but this incident caused us to say hmmm ok bye Felicia! 1st and last time there! If you want a great sub and service just go to Baris!

I heard of this place because I liked the bread at this restaurant and this is where the order it from  Holy cow ! 10inch sandwich on fresh bake bread ! I got the Italian - hot peppers, salami, capicola, mortadella !!! Lettuce !tomato! All for 6.75 !  This sandwich is the epitome of all evil !! I was tempted to eat all 10inch of this mouth watering fresh cut sandwich ! I was only being greedy ! And my stomach is already hanging over my stretch pants.  On to the cookies, I got an assortment and so far tried the biscotti and sprinkled cookies, so delicious , broke in my mouth (the good kind of crumbling ) and I didn't lose a tooth .   I will def be coming back !

I have not had a better square in the city.  This place is just amazing to me.  If I lived in the area I would be a regular, hell I would ask if they can teach me.  Their bread, the pizza, and the Italian Ice or as I call it Wooder Ice (lady was very confused when I asked for that. They have amazing sandwiches and can't wait to try some of the cookies and such that they have.  I am not sure if they cater or what, but I am sure I would use them if they did.
The pizza is so good it's almost incomprehensible. And the focaccia bread is super on point. Carb heaven!

I have had this pizza for 50 years, still the best. Great sandwiches, the best Latte with a hint of cinnamon, the paste ties are by far the best. No I'm not family, if you have yet to try their cannoli, stop and get one. The ricotta is creamed to perfection. Need I say more, you must stop in.

Cannoli- OMG Pizza - not the prettiest, but flavor, crust, texture, sauce OMG Huge selection of cookies, tarts, breads and lovely morsels. You can have subs freshly made as well. After biking over 20 miles I'm glad we were so famished it made us stop at a new place. Oh the smells. We had the non chocolate cannoli, probably the best I've ever had. Perfect pastry, lovely filling. Mmmm. Too bad the coffee machine wasn't working. Lemon tart with merengue was good though the merengue was marshmallowy and the lemon filling was a fluffy cream. It was difficult to love because of how damn good the cannoli was. We will be back. Hopefully after another long bike ride to warrant the old world calories of carby, fatty and sweet goodness!

I just got back from Italy last night and my friend Daniel (who is kind of fat) brought this in for work lunch and I just had a couple slices fat pizza (how apropos) and I have to say I'm really effing happy that I ate some.  TJ the hipster (who has also been to Italy) also approves.  I had something like this in Florence and it bangs with it.  Is anyone else sick of hearing about FIFA?  I am.

I love D'amato's. The pizza is awesome, reminds me of the pizza I grew up on in Niagara Falls, NY! I also love the focaccia, I get my sandwiches built on it and it is enough for two full meals. Cannolis are too sweet for my taste which bummed me out, but I'll stick to the breads and I'll be a fan for life. Beware, cash only!
I like the restaurant with the Italian style.  Look at the cashier machine. Their pizza and sandwichs are awesome
Generally, this wouldn't be my kind of place, but they have the best tuna melt in the city for only $5. The boyfriend loves their pizza slices too, which are $2.50 a piece.

Wow, you know that feeling when you know you should stop eating but you just can't?  I got that today while devouring one of D'amato's meatball subs. I called it quit not once but twice only to unroll my sandwich and finish it off. Really great. I wish I would've saved some room for some of their sweets.

Co-worker sent me here to pick up a few things! Oh man let me start off by saying I've been craving a good Italian sub the past few years and could never find one...but I did at D'Amato's! I can't wait to come back for more! Cannoli was delicious too! Both very authentic! Service was okay, probably not in a good mood since it was later in the day. I would recommended that they use gloves or parchment paper for picking up some items that they sell to their customers especially right after handling cash. But overall great place for great food!

I finally stopped in here for lunch - slice of pizza and a can of pop cost $3.25!  And the pizza was outstanding! I don't know how I didn't come here sooner.  I can't wait to go back to try the sandwiches and desserts.

Their pizza is unlike any other.  Not heavy handed on the cheese.  Love the artichoke olive and the mushroom green pepper.  Just cheese is awesome as well.  Can't get out of there without a variety of cookies, biscotti and a brownie.  Popular spot so don't go in there an hour before close and expect a large selection.
Amazing cannoli, great sandwiches too. Cash only, but there's an atm on the corner. Espresso's good too! Very authentic and the place has been around forever. Good good
Real traditional Italian pastries, breads & mini pizzas to die for. Simple yet real ingredients, w/everything made from scratch, make the most amazing foods at times.
My Sunday spot, come for the sandwiches leave with $30 in cookies.  I'm looking forward to a weekend where my girlfriend is out of town so I can order a 3ft'r and eat it all without being judged.

My bf brought pizza home the other day from here and it was delicious.  Reminded me of my favorite Neapolitan pizza that I get tin Boston. Definitely want to go back to try different pizza varieties and other bakery products.  Only downside is having to warm up the pizza yourself at home - though that may have been my fiance's bad for not asking.

THE BEST Bread I ever tried! Amen! Sometimes I Travel there only cause I want a bite Of Bread. During the lunch Time, there is a huge Line inside, sometimes even outside. People like those sandwiches. I do to. Pretty GOOD coffee and great pastries. You don't believe me? Try brownie. But not only that. They also sell pizzas, pastas.

Amazing cannoli, cookies, & pizza.  Whenever I travel, I try to seek out authentic Italian bakeries as good cannoli are so hard to find.  I currently live in Utah, so I make my own.  D'amato's is every bit as good as homemade, & certainly much easier.  I highly recommend it.
The Sicilian style pizza by the slice was great and super cheap. The will warm a slice up for you there. The focaccia bread was fab too. The Italian cookies are a must.

This is an old fashioned bread bakery down to the register and the bags.  They have french bread, cookies, pizza bread, cannoli, and focaccia among other things ready to go.  The bread is awesome I got one loaf for home and one for the ride home, hehehe!!!!!  In the summer they also have Italian ice.  Sometimes in the winter too, of your lucky!!!!! The price is not cheap, nor expensive, but it's worth it. Highly recommended.

A little off the beaten path if you're downtown but SOOOOO worth it. Just take the blue line to Grand then walk down Grand street away from the city a few blocks to experience the BEST cannoli you have ever tasted. Super fresh pastry and the ricotta filling is sweet, delicious and full of pistachios. Coffee is fresh, service is fast and friendly. Limited seating - it's really a takeout bakery. Yum, yum, yum!!

Cannoli: Awesome. Focaccia pan pizza: Excellent. Ladies working there: Smoking hot. Not sure what else you could possiblty be looking for, but as far as Italian bakeries go, D'Amato's is a good as it gets. The only downfall here is there is only one table indoors, so if that is taken you have have nowhere interally to eat your cannoli.
Great slices of bakery pizza!  Delicious.  Their french bread is amazing for any sandwich.  Sandwiches are decent, but go next door instead... Bari is much better.

Yummy bakery! Ordered a wide selection of sweets, pizza and a baguette. The pizza was very good, almost like focaccia pan pizza. Their cookies were delish. This was my first cannoli and it wasn't that great. The lobster tail was good tho!  We went to the deli next door and bought some homemade sausages, antipasto and some cheese. We had a fab little meal!

I stumbled upon this awesome bakery, after eating at Butterfly Thai Restaurant, across the way. Let me just say, it was the greatest thing that has ever happened to my taste buds! BEST.CANOLI.EVER. While the canoli is very satisfying when you're in the mood for something sweet, the loaf of Italian bread and Sourdough is oh so yummy! Sometimes I make the drive into the city, just to satisfy my craving! So worth the 45 minute drive!

I love D'amato's!  They are a weekly lunch spot for me and my colleagues being conveniently located around the corner that is. Their pizza's a quick and delicious, cookies are to die for and their fruit tart is my guilty pleasure!  So happy they're making subs now too :)

Got eclairs, bad idea. You think that there's going to be a lot of heavy custard in it because it's so heavy, but no, all the weight comes from the icing- which tastes like the stuff you buy in a tub. The 'custard', which is more like cream, tastes overly sugary and isn't thick at all. I scraped off almost all of the icing and the eclair suddenly got a lot lighter. The service was good, but I would not recommend getting french pastries at an italian place.

All you need to know about D'amato's is the 3 S's. Slices, sandos, and it's super cheap. Yes...they've got cannoli and a bunch of other baked goods (which I'm sure are also awesome) but if you stick to the savory stuff you'll be a happy camper.  Slices are only 2 bucks a pop and melt in your mouth delicious. Sandwiches aren't quite 5 dollar footlongs, but they're a-tad-above-that-price for ten inches of bakery bread, quality meats, and fresh fixens. It's worth may more than the price you're paying. Try the beef and meatball combo or do either alone and I'm sure you'll agree.  Cash only and their ATM has a $3.50. Pretty much the only negative about this place. Other than that it's solid gold.

HOLY CANNOLI Batman! This place is "Da chit"! I don't know how and the heck I overlooked this place for so long, as we try to come to Chicago once a year for a getaway.  The food here is amazing, and CHEAP! We ordered a giant cannoli for my daughters birthday, and ended up buying about half of the store while we were in there. Sure, it's not a "pizzaria" , and, it's not trying to be. But it does darned good, as it's a bakery..and this place does bread GOOD. Giant cannoli...$55. Focaccia...$4. Pizza square...$1. Regular cannoli...$2 Pies, cheesecakes, cookies, pizzas, subs..... MAKE ROOM....I MOVING IN!!!!!

It was 11:30 on a Sunday morning and I was looking for an Italian sub before the Bears game kicked off.  I jumped in the car and headed over to Bari's.  When I walked in, there were about 15 people in line at the deli counter and I thought, "This isn't going to work. I'll never make kickoff!".  What's a guy to do?  I remembered that D'Amato's had started making sandwiches not too long ago.  (Something about a feud with Bari's over bread and deciding to start making subs as an F-YOU.)  I walked next door and quickly had my Italian sub and a cannoli for the road.  I was back at home and in front of the big screen before the game started.  Best of all, the sub was great- comparable to what I had gone to Bari's for and on that great D'Amato's bread that Bari's has replaced with a not-as-good substitute.  All in all, a really great decision and a really great sandwich.  Best of all, because of the quick decision, I also had a fantastic cannoli for dessert!
Meh. Cookies lack texture and they were mushy. Nice flavors but come on a cookie should be somewhat crunchy...

Okay, first off be aware that this place is cash only. They even have a super old school cash register up front with mechanical levers. It makes for a nice old-timey experience, but personally I'd rather forgo it and pay with a credit card. That's my only complaint about them though. Absolutely everything else is awesome. The staff are friendly, the service is quick, the prices are reasonable, and most importantly, the bread is delicious. Yes, it's going to be a few dollars more than at Jewel, but trust me, it's worth it. You can hear it crunching if you give is a light squeeze, so you know it's basically just come out of the oven. It's also super soft inside, and works well for anything: sandwiches, grilled cheese, side to a soup, you name it. The downside to buying fresh bread is of course that it goes stale faster than a typical mass-produced bread from Jewel because it's got no preservatives in it (though I guess that's also an upside). I usually throw it in the fridge right after buying it, and then microwave each piece I cut off thereafter for about 30 seconds to soften it, but it does become kind of a hassle.  On another note, their cannoli taste like angels are dancing in your mouth, and they're covered with pistachios!

What a great little sandwich shop.  The best part?  The Price!!!! So cheap!  I stopped in for a slice of pizza and was surprised by the selection.  Pizzas, subs, sandwiches, breads, desserts...you name it!  Reminds me of those narrow street shops in Italy.  I will definitely be back if I'm in the area.

My fist experience with D'Amato's involved a carry-out order of cheese, sausage, and artichoke pizzas for a work celebration. The pizza is unlike your typical Chicago deep dish or New York-style flat pizza. Its more like a large rectangular piece of focaccia bread, with a chewy and dense crust and minimal toppings. Like most bread, it tastes best when warm. The paper packaging does little to keep the pizza warm, so I recommend eating this stuff ASAP.  The pizza is relatively inexpensive, and is great for work or birthday parties if you're on a budget!

Great cookies and espresso! I ordered a slice to eat here and sadly they forgot about it. When they finally did being it-barely warm. I could understand if they were very busy, but it wasn't. Great food, disappointing service.
Amazing subs and panini's. Old school Italian bakery. I would give 5 starts if they accepted credit/debit. It's cash only (no checks).  Staff could be a little friendly as well.

Having lived in NYC for a bit, I greatly miss New York style pizza, well there, the confession is out in the open. I miss the slices but also the squares, which they advertise as "Sicilian" pizza. So when I asked the Sicilian guy at work, he said there's no such thing. Then I asked our Sicilian contractor and he recommended D'Amato's - and so glad he did! Their thick focaccia style squares are delicious, especially if you eat it fresh and warm. Their focaccia is delicious too!  But their cookies stole my heart! I can survive a whole week on just their cookies! They melt in your mouth and pair so well with coffee! The cannolis are probably one of the best I've had so far, the only two that compare are in Little Italy in NYC & Boston.
The cookies. My God.  D'amato's is a Chicago institution. If you haven't already been here, go now.

I haven't tried their pastries, but D'amato's pizza is great! It's made on a light, fluffy, focaccia-like crust with minimal cheese. Super inexpensive, $2-$2.50 per big rectangular piece. If you're lucky enough to get a piece hot out of the oven it's even better. I'm a fan of the sausage but even the plain cheese is really good. Cash only.

This review is based only on the pizza. Its seriously amazing. Like in the top 3 pizza's in Chicago. I dont eat cookies and what not so cant review on that but honestly, if the pizza was not likely terrible for your health, I would eat it everyday. Its reasonably priced and very greasy but man, great dough, great sauce, its just great. I actually might go get a slice right now.

Absolutely fabulous!!!! The foccacia bread with delicious toppings, flat rounds with thinley sliced tomatoes and olive oil, assorted melt in your mouth Italian cookies and coffee are worth the journey. Not far from Clark St. We took a cab there and then walked back to our hotel with cookies in hand.

Dat focaccia bread, tho! Sure, it's just one thing on a long list of offered baked goods and sandwiches at D'amato's, but that one thing was all it took for me.  Freaking thick-ass, salted black olives on that bad boy and I was in heaven. They offered to warm it up for me at the shop but I'd planned on taking it home as a sort of consolation present for SO, whom did not get an invite to the dinner I was attending.  I heated that ish up at home the next day with my partner and we dined like kings on a single loaf of some damn delicious olive focaccia.  Be forewarned: Ordering is definitely a stressful sitch.  You really won't get time to look at a menu or even scan the shop offerings in full, you'll need to be ready with your order stat, so know that it might take you a few trips in to actually have an opportunity to see enough of the store to know what they offer.  It's cash only, so be ready with your dolla dolla bills and if you happen to become a pro and are able to audibly get a sandwich order in, you can seat yourself outside on their pretty adorable neighborhood that plays some pretty rad tunes over outdoor speakers.

Damn those sammies are delish.  So far in Chicago it's Fiores vs D'amato's for deli sammies title.  The small round thin pizza's here are good too.  I'm not a fan of the thicker bread pizza's but who am I to judge?  Also, all of that bread everywhere in the store gets me pretty randy. I just want to shove it all in a pillow case and lie down so I can dream of a world where i never go without your bread.
wham bam thank you ma'am....D'amatos pizza haunts my dreams! Watch out whoever has the #1 check ins for this place cause I'm #2 and gainin'...
Go. It's wonderful. Just skim the rest of the reviews. Their pizza, dessert, and coffee are all perfect. 5 stars Recommendation: Everything

I stop by las week Me & my kids They almost ready to close 7 pm Is cash only Convenient atm next door The lady that took my order kind rush me.... So i order Ham & cheese   Meatbalk & italian sub and some cookies Was really good See you next time early !!!!!!!
Seems to be a bit better than average food. I wasn't super impressed with the service with seemed a bit snippy.

I went there today for the first time. Tried my first Cannoli in my life. It was amazing, Also I got a 10 inches Caprese Sub. All together is 8 dollars, and the sub is so big, I can only eat half of it. There are so much mozzarella inside my sub, I was so so so happy. And the Cannoli is great :) I love it, I just wish I can try all of the things in this place. definitely go there again soon

I was kinda disappointed by this bakery but maybe because I just came from Boston and they have a great Italian bakery there that blew my mind. I shared the zeppole with my friend but it felt like it had been sitting out for quite a while... :-( probably won't be coming back because none of the cookies and pastries looked that fresh! The zeppole yellow cream custard was delicious but the pastry dough was soggy. They do have a wide selection though... but their cannolis are filled in advance.

Thank God I don't get to go here more often, I would be huge.  I love their cannoli's and their Italian cookies.  Everything here is fresh and good.  Make sure you go next door and pickup a sub while you are here, they are awesome too.
absolute heaven!  we have been going here since the 70's.  when you eat a good meal you gotta have great bread. when you walk in you'll faint from the incredible aroma : )
Great food, great prices, friendly staff.  These people know what they are doing. I especially love the Italian cookies and pizza.

Thank God D'amato's is a slightly too-far walk from my apartment to make sense on a bitter winter day.  Because if it was just a little closer, I'd be eating subs, cannoli, and italian cookies every meal of the day all winter.  I've tried the afore mentioned items, as well as the loaves of italian bread (sooooo good), and have been happy with every purchase.  Those buttery cookies with the fudgy swirly topping?  Stop.  Fresh cannoli?  Stop.  Delicious subs with fresh ingredients for under six bucks.  No, really.  STOP. I feel like I'm walking into someone's house when I go here; it's got a strong family feel and very friendly staff.  Good hours too.  I can't wait for spring!

I have never had a cannoli in my entire life and suffice it say, D'amato's was the perfect choice for my first. Their chocolate cannoli and a slice of cheese pizza with a can of Dr. Pepper made for a pleasant lunch. Even the bread on their pizza was so soft, it felt like it was melting in my mouth! Even though they don't accept cards, I do appreciate that all their prices are listed with tax and the fact that they have an antique (and functional) cash register.

You don't' have to look elsewhere for pastries, Pizzas or cookies. What D'amato's produces is out of this world. Why? Well, if you're looking for a real pizza, then you've found the true pizza slice joint. They are more Italian in preparation with more bread toppings as opposed to the Cheeses at all of the American version but that doesn't reduce the savory experience.  The fruit filled cookies are awesome and you get tasty and fresh quality all the time. Talking of pastries, I almost passed out with pleasure because of the great flavor of the chocolate filled cannoli. Their subs are comparable to Bari's both in price and quantity. I am glad I moved into the neighborhood recently because I don't need to put to much energy and time into preparing a meal with the wonderful sandwiches they introduced lately. This is one place that is convenient and offers good value for your money.
I'm going to go back here to try the sandwiches. I grabbed a cannoli and Americano to go. The service and coffee were so very nice! I love the atmosphere of this Italian bakery deli coffee shop
Fantastic food!! I'm currently loving the "knots".!   I have had nothing but good service and I will defiantly keep coming back!!!
Visiting from Texas.  Found this bakery on yelp.  Freshness of cookies was on point.  Couldn't find anything like this anywhere else near our hotel.  Cool register from 1862.

Great neighborhood spot, feels like grandmas kitchen (if she was Italian, not Chinese).  My staples are the arancini, focaccia pizzas (better warmed in oven), and Italian bread.  There also great single serve dinners like chicken parm with pasta for $8.  This is also coming from a kid who grew up this plenty of Italian joints in NJ and NY.

I'v been eating cannolsi my entire life, (im 50). born in Italy. Best freakin cannoli EVER. fresh, perfect shell, creamy filling not to sweet just right. perfect pistachio cover. This is the way GOD intended cannolis to be made.

People will rave about the pizza, cookies, sandwiches, foccacia but for me this place is all about the bread. When I was a kid my dad would pick up bread from here a couple times a month. Yes, this place has been around a while. It hasn't changed over the years although I think the sandwiches are an addition. Well, anyway, back to the bread. I think there's nothing better than having some of their bread with a little butter. Keeping it simple. I also like the vegetarian pizzas and foccacias.

D'Amato's is great! I've been going here at least once a week for almost a year now. Everything i've ever had is always fresh and delicious! I think i've had almost everything too... Everyone always greets you with a smile and is quick to take care of business and get you your order. Only downside (which i totally understand from a business perspective) is it's CASH ONLY. Cause if they'd take cards, i'd probably pick up a lot more when i'm staring at all the deliciousness on the counter.

I live upstairs. I've had a million subs. CASH ONLY. The meatball sub is my personal favorite with mozzarella and hot peppers. Their Macaroons are my favorite cookie also, try them if you like coconut. I've had the pizza by the slice a few times and it is pretty good also for around $2/slice. They heat it up for you. Nice staff but be ready to order when you're at the counter.

Ok. You can tell by the ratings this place is great. So, I'm not really writing this review for you. It's just in case the fine folks at d'amato's read these reviews - which I doubt! It seems like every time I go in there the girls up front find new ways to inconvenience me and/or annoy me. Recently, walked in in the middle of a rain storm soaking wet to get their fine baked goods. There was only one other customer beside me in the store and four girls working the front. One girl helped the guy ahead of me; two girls worked on cleaning a display case, while the fourth girl talked to them. I stood around for several minutes before one of them finally came around and took my order. D'amato's you've got great baked goods! Love everything from the breads, to the cannoli, to the cookies. Just want to see if we can work on getting customer service from D- to C. Accepting credit/debit cards will automatically get you to a B+ in customer service! To be fair, I don't know of a better Italian bakery in the city!

This place is so great, but CASH ONLY so come prepared.   The food is amazing- their delicious bread is definitely the secret.  Sandwiches, pizza by the slice, pastries and even refrigerated meals to go.  They put love into everything and you can taste it!

i vote d'amatos over bari.  why?  because the d'amatos makes a better version of the sandwich i order.  don't get me wrong, bari is wonderful.  but d's is just slightly better, for me, personally. i usually order the prosciutto/mozz/basil sub.  for whatever reason (magic, made by elves, made with love, made with crack), their sub is a lot tastier and less dry.  i've done this taste test 3 times, since i am a fatty.  and d's wins, hands down. come in, order at the disorganized but friendly counter amongst all the cute meatheads, wait for them to call your name.  sit outside (boner, i mean bonus) on their beautiful patio, weather permitting.  they also have delicious looking pizzas! other honorable mentions: pros: THEY HAVE COOKIES. cons: cash only.  sad trombone.

Best sausage foccacia bread which is pillowy  soft.  Great prices on cappuccinos or lattes as well.  I bought 3 foccacia breads,  a an of pop and a cappuccino for about 10, they only accept cash but have an atm outside in case you forgot.  The cannolis are also excellent.  If you are in the area this is a must stop.

Extremely important tips: 1. Cash only 2. Tomato & olive focaccia I lived in Chicago for 3.5 years and I'm so mad at myself for not coming here sooner! I was in awe from this authentic Italian bakery and it's fresh products. I love the simplicity and personality of this place.  It's a smaller store, but who cares, get in and get out. They've mastered the art of keeping an old school family bakery genuine through the years, beyond refreshing and charming.  On my first visit, I circled to find parking but realized how busy it was, a constant and steady stream of people. With all the options in Chicago, you know that's a great sign. When I first walked in, not gonna lie, I was slightly intimidated, or maybe just excited. Either way it took me a few minutes to order even though I knew what I wanted. I realized everyone who came in had been there probably a million times. By the time they walked in and out it only took MAYBE 2 minutes. These people were pros. And after trying the tomato olive focaccia, I know why.  I originally stopped in because I heard they were the best when it came to authentic, no BS focaccia. They're are multiple options, original focaccia ($2, 4inch diameter) with tomato then topping combinations from tomato and olive to artichoke to onion etc. The options with multiple toppings are $4, 8inch diameter, huge but I probably could have devoured it alone. Dangerously good.  They also offer pizza, cookies, Italian ice, probably more but that's all I could take in. I plan on going back ASAP for more focaccia and to snap pictures of their masterpieces!
After trying nearby vinnys and Bari for subs,  we decided to give the Italian sandwich at this place a try. Excellent. Great flavor, fresh meat, bread and cheese. We will be back.

I had the chocolate horn, cannoli, and the original focaccia bread. Chocolate horn was definitely fresh and not overly sweet, and soft. I never had a good experience with cannolis so I decided to find the best cannoli I can find in town and I landed here. D'amatos' cannoli was crispy which was already a bonus 'cause the last cannoli I had was soft and slightly wet. The pistachios definitely gave a nice flavor and texture to the cannoli but the cream/filling...overly sweet. So conclusion: I still don't really like cannolis but I'm open minded to try another one if it's any good. The focaccia bread was yummy. It was the size of a personal pizza! I looked at it and thought, okay..maybe I should take a knife to cut it into pieces to eat it at home. But what end up happening was me driving home and munched off the bread every so often. It was just that good or maybe I have no self-restraint.

The pizza is delicious! Sold in square slices and VERY cheap (I think $2 or less). Served at room temperature. The base of the pizza is like a soft bread. They put dimples in the crust and spread it with tomato sauce and then toppings. There isn't a ton of cheese on these pizzas. On a Saturday morning around 11am, there were at least 4 different pizzas with a variety of toppings available (sausage, pepperoni, various vegetables, etc). I also purchased a small tomato and cheese focaccia and a large focaccia with tomatoes and mushrooms. They were also excellent. The outer inch or so of the focaccia is quite crusty/crunchy but the interior is softer. They also sell pastries and loaves of bread. Easy street parking. Cash only. Highly recommend.
YOUZ GUYZ GOTTA GO HERE. The pizza slices are awesome. The turtle cookies with chocolate and caramel are great. The service is great.

We live in the neighborhood and have lots of choices for Italian bakeries. That said, the bread from D'amato's can't be beat. The bread is always perfectly baked with a crisp, delicious crust.  But you have to ask yourself - is the bad customer service worth the good bread? Sometimes yes and sometimes no. Today was a definite no. The young woman with the brown pony tail was not only curt and rude to me, she was also condescending and rude to an apparently new hire, snarling at the poor woman "Just put it in a bag - maybe you can handle that" with total disdain, causing the new hire to sink back into the wall even farther. When I asked for a receipt for my purchase - which I wasn't offered - Miss Pony Tail refused to acknowledge my request and simply barked at the next customer for their order. After standing around for a few minutes while she avoided me completely (with the frightened new hire shrugging sympathetically at me) she disappeared into the back room until after I left the store in disgust -  without my receipt. And, oh by the way,  Sicilian cannoli's are garnished with pistachio nuts (or chocolate chips or candied fruit)  - not peanuts. But then there is that bread........
Italian ice, sub sandwiches, pizza, cannolis, bakery cookies, breads... All under one roof. Super clean, super efficient. Love this place.

we bought both the custard filled flake pastry and the famed cannoli, and they were both really disappointing. the cannoli shell was so hard to the point but it doesn't break apart when needed. the custard in the pastry was lumpy and the pastry was not flaky at all.

I live across the street, so I may be biased... But I LOVE this place. My favorite things currently include... the pepperoni pizza, focaccia, lemon knots, lemon square, apple squres, seasame sticks, meatballs subs, eclairs, multigrain bread, mufalda.... I haven't been dissapointed by anything I've tried. The gals that work here are great too!

Yesterday was my turn to buy dinner. I was suggested to buy sub style sandwiches but not from subway. I ask for a place and D'amatos came to the top of the list.  I stopped at the ATM before heading tot his great place because I was warned that it's a cash only establishment. As soon as I entered the bakery, I was in love. I have a fascination for old world bakeries and D'amatos did not disappoint me. A very polite attendant welcomed me. I told her that it was my first time at their establishment and she said "take your time, you'll like everything we have." Their wide selection of breads is outstanding. I immediately grabbed what it looked like a 5 feet baguette and wanted to get one of everything else. Their focaccia breads looked great and at $3, you can't go wrong. Their pizza looked very good too. I came to my senses and looked at the wide variety of subs and ordered two. I ordered the foot long sized sandwiches to go.  I ordered the Italian meats for my boyfriend and a prosciutto with bacon and fresh mozzarella for me. I also took two of their lemon bars. The attendant was very welcoming and engaged me in conversation. She invited me for next time to come and eat at their outside patio. It definitely could be a great idea. For everything I took home I only paid $21. Excellent value. The sandwiches are outstanding. I could only finish half of the sandwich last night and the other half I just had it for lunch. Very tasty.  This is on my list of places to visit more frequently for sure. Outstanding food, outstanding service, great value!

D'Amato's is the other half of a 1-2 punch on Grand because it is right next door to Bari. The bread is excellent, and is partly responsible for the tastiness of the subs next door. the pizza is also pretty good and cheap! It can be pretty chaotic inside when the line is long but the staff is very nice. I was once served by the owner's daughter, and she was so friendly and helpful. A note on hygiene: can you please use tongs or paper to grab the bread/pastries. It's pretty gross to see the staff handle cash or sweep, and then reach for your bread without washing their hands. I definitely saw this and was icked out. Also beware, it's cash only.

D'amatos - you make me sad.  I was expecting to enjoy a stellar cannoli from you.  After all, who knows italian dessert better than an italian bakery - right?  So WHY are there green dyed peanuts on the ends of your cannolis?  A traditional cannoli has pistachios.  Do you really think that no one will notice the strong and distinctly peanut flavoring of those nutty morsels?  The light complexity of the pistachio in combination with the crispy shell and dense creamy filling is the essence of the cannoli itself.   Are pistachios really that expensive? The cannoli was delicious in every other way - but PLEASE - I beg you to reconsider the peanuts.  Please.....

i can't wait to come back to this place and order another sub sandwich and a few desserts!  my husband came back from an errand with a few sub sandwiches and cannoli's. i  had half of an italian sub and later the prosciutto with mozzarella.  the bread is made at the bakery and has this great crusty crunch when you sink your teeth into the sandwich. yum-o!  love their cannoli; it's super yummy.

What isn't to love about D'amato's.  My parents have been frequenting this establishment since I was a little girl - even brining me pizza and goodies when I was away at college years ago.  It wasn't until I got older than I realized how great it was to live near such an awesome bakery. Their pizza is amazing!  Yes, it is a little greasy and not a traditional pizza but that is what makes it soo good.  Same for their different focaccia breads.  Also, their cookies are always so fresh.  I recently brought a box to my friend that was in the hospital and everyone commented on how tasty and fresh they were.   Love that I can stop here the day before a major holiday or party and pick up everything I need, including bread and some of the best cannolis in the city.  I am pretty sure they are still a cash only place so keep that in mind if you are checking them out for the first time and ENJOY!!

I wish there were two ways to rate this bakery.  If I were rating the service by the staff, I would give it 1 star.  The girls were not friendly, and I did  not feel welcome into their establishment.  HOWEVER, I felt a bit like the Seinfeld episode with the soup Nazi, because their staff could have been cold and rude all day long if I could get my hands on one of their cannoli's there!  They are unbelievably delicious!!!!  Every little cookie we bought, were each unique and absolutely scrumptious.  I will definitely go back for their product, NOT their service!  Oh, and make sure you take cash with you, but they do have a very convenient ATM right outside.

A visit to D'amato's Bakery requires some preparation.  First of all: -Bring cash or go home hungry -Be ready to go up some steep steps or just walk on by.  If you have a stroller with you, come in pairs.  Leave the partner and the stroller outside or work as a team if it starts raining. -Order quickly by golly because nobody and I mean NOBODY has time for that looking and choosing nonsense. -Be prepared to be barked at. I came home with cookies and an eclair.  I might have ordered more had I not felt super rushed, nervous and under performing.  They were all really really good.  I enjoyed them but would never go out of my way to shop here again.  If I was next door, I might buy some more but it's such an intense experience to get a few cookies. Overall, really good baked goods in a boot camp atmosphere.

Chocolate Dipped Cannoli: My rating is based purely on this.  The cannoli was decent and I wished I had been a little less adventurous and ordered only this.   The other items listed below were dry, bland, and disappointing.  Pastry filled with raspberry mouse: I remember a pastry with no mouse. I would describe it more as a weird gelatin floury mush thing.  Lobster tail filled with french cream: I had my very first at Mike's Pastry Shop in Boston, and sadly the version here was such a disappointment.  The pastry tail was soggy and more chewy. There was no freshness to the bite.  The cream was dense, lumpy, and custard like vs the lighter cream that I prefered at Mike's.  Pastry filled with custard: It was similar to the lobster style in taste and texture, but of a different form ... this was more rectangular rather than bugle shaped.  The place was incredibly busy, with most ordering the fresh baguettes and breads.  Perhaps I ordered the wrong things?

Can't leave this place without one of the following: 1) Pizza bread (Think pan pizza but much, much better) 2) Something sweet. (Anything I've tried cookies, cannoli whatever. Its all good.) 2) Long loaf of bread. (awesome for sandwiches or during dinner.) My dad and mom used to take me here when I was a kid. It hasn't changed much in the best kind of way!
This place is amazing and the price is right. Everything is so fresh and delectable. I highly recommend this place for a sandwich or any type of pastry. A must try.

I must admit that I throw all caution to the wind when I enter D'Amato's Bakery.  Why? Well, I really should not be eating bread. I have an intolerance to grains but I will risk it just to eat even a tiny morsel of D'Amato's Italian bread. The crust is so crunchy. I always buy at least one Italian baguette. I love to eat it with homemade Mexican chocolate.  I am also a fan of their cannoli. Again, I should not be eating cannoli but a girl must indulge ever so often. I usually only eat a small piece and share the rest. Anywhoo. The cannoli shells are the perfect texture and crunch. The filling is out of this world. I wish I could buy a bucket of the filling. The edges are dipped and covered with pistachio nuts. Their unique recipe makes D'Amato's Bakery cannoli the best in Chicago.  Disclaimer: As a teen, I worked at an Italian bakery and had to learn to fill cannoli so I know my cannoli. Take my word, check out D'Amato's cannoli.
Downgrade.  Added sandwiches.  They are good, but not nearly as their deli competitor next door.  Longer lines and no credit cards.

D'amato's is great. How great? Really great. If that doesn't satisfy you, here are some details: Strong advocate of Bari subs, but I took a chance on D'amato's, which they recently started offering, a week or two ago. They are comparable to Bari's, but they use the D'amato's bread, which I have to say is superior. Their pricing structure is the same (about $4.50 for a 9", $5-6 for a 12") and they are made in about the same time. No disrespect to Bari, but it's worth trying D'amato's to see which you prefer. Their bread is second to none and about $3 (with tax) per loaf. Their cookies are exceptional. Not sure how much Italian cookies are supposed to cost, but these run about $8/lb. There are at least 3 dozen types to choose from. Strongly suggested for family gatherings, huge hit. I will say that it's incredibly annoying that they don't accept credit cards, but whatever. Just make sure to bring cash.  All in all, 5 stars. It's great that places like this still exist.

Top notch! My dad used to stop here on his way home from work when I was a kid and bring home bread, focacha and it still tastes amazing. Its been years since I have been here and I am glad I made the trip. I stopped in just for a slice of brick oven pizza that was amazing. Light fluffy crust and tasted great. Brought me back to the days my dad would bring some home. Very small place you're in and out once you order. Not really anywhere to sit and eat so grab and go. But oh so worth it!!

Where to begin with this place? It's amazing. Everything about this place is amazing. Luckily for my taste buds (not so luckily for my waistline), this little treasure is located about a block away from my place. Every time I make a pilgrimage here, which can be frequent, I am greeted by the friendly staff, the sound of their antique register and the smell of baked goods.  The sandwiches are delicious with my favorite being the veggie - a 10 inch fresh Italian baguette, slices of tomato, pickled artichoke hearts, fresh mozzarella, arugula, and light dress. In addition, the baked goods are to die for. The canolis are amazing - crunchy, with a light cream in the center and a hard chocolate shell on the outside.  My FAVORITE FAVORITE FAVORITE dessert from D'Amato's is the chocolate covered horn. A light, flakey, croissant-like texture filled with raspberry filling, cream, and dipped in chocolate.  If you haven't experienced D'Amatos, do yourself a favor and go. It's cash only, but an ATM is located side of the building.

Yup - this is going in my mental list of good and cheap eats. I got the chocolate covered raspberry cream puff and it is exquisite. I like the slightly thicker shell which you can taste the buttery, flaky doughness. This is going to sound funny, but I've been looking for chocolate covered pastries that resembled like the ones found in a Japanese train station, 8 years later searching all over the US, Frankfurt, Munich and Paris, it's been here in Chicago all this time!! Refined smooth dark chocolate..mmm. Thought the pizza was just okay, it's probably more Italian, not American, where it's less cheese and more bread toppings like whole olives, artichoke hearts, etc. For a small shop, it runs a big buisiness, tons of food ready to go and lots of charm. And like everywhere else in the world, taxes are included. Makes a lot sense seeing that it must be rung up on cash with an old timey register. Canolli + cappuccino, you're next.

Went here because it's my friend's favorite bakery.  The cookies were ok (warning, I think they come in sets of 3, because I asked for a few kinds thinking I was getting 1 of each, and accidentilly walked out with about 9 cookies!)  Flatbreads were very good.  Bread was awesome.  I loved the old cash register, and the prices were more than reasonable!
This is a really cool spot!  Very old school vibe.  The foccacia bread pizza was excellent, and you can't go wrong with the cookies with sprinkles on top.  The staff was friendly but slow.
