Tomato pizza; amazing, Arancini; look amazing (they've been out of the meat ones both times i've gone!!!), canolli; delicious. I'm Sicilian, and the canollis at this place compare to ones i've had in Sicily.  Great staff, quick service, delicious food!

I tried D'amato's after my 65 year old Sicilian co worker suggested it. The caprese sub is incredible and enough for my husband and I to share (leaving room for some cannoli or pastries of course).  I only knocked off a star because they are cash only. I hate paying an independent ATM fee because the owner wants to save 2% on credit card transactions.

Their breads and pastries are top notch but the low review is for their other items.  Their arrancinin used to be so delicious and now they seem to be mass producing them and their fillings are not very good anymore.  They also are making entrees but the sauces are bland and the pasta is overcooked.  I'm not certain why they are branching out to do something that they don't do that well.  Their traditional items like pizza and cookies still rock!

I use to love the cannoli at this place but on Thursday jan 10 2013 I got some and they where gross. I think the sandwich business got in the way of the cannoli art  all the girl try too sell was the subs. i always go to Bari for my subs ..

Ive been coming here since a kid, my favorite part about this place is the pizza! Very different than most pizza places and just amazing! Bread and focaccia bread is amazing also. I keep forgetting cash only but oh well not gonna knock off a star for my horrible memory

Customer Service Stopped by this place on my way to Bary Italians Sub around Saturday 2p, was greeted by the owner and asked what wed like. Told her we needed a few minutes since it was our first time.  After a minute or so we were finally ready. We asked for assistance from one of the 4 people available to assist, but now we were being ignored. Finally we got someone to help us (the owners daughter) and instead of addressing us, she decides to call a new employee over to show her how to treat a customer. Finally managed to tell her what we wanted, chocolate, and regular  canolies. The owners daughter starts showing the new hire how to get the item. Take a piece of wax paper and put the  canolies together on one tray (ok so far), but then out of no where since the  canolies were not easy to gather since they would rolled down the pan she decided to uses her fingers.  Maybe she thought that one could not see through the glass showcase but here's a news flash, you can. It does not end there. After putting the  canolies in the bag as she goes to give them to me, she drops them on the floor. No sorry or anything, she picks them up and hands them to me. I in turn told me I wanted different ones. This time forget the wax paper she went all out finger. If I would have been alone I would have walked out. Cannoli Now to the  canolies. Got them home, and after tasting, the cream had nothing special. No ricotta or mascarpone taste, no texture. The shell however was flaky/crunchy like and ok in taste.  If it had not been because of the customer service I think it would have deserved one more star.Maybe.

Wow.  We came to Chicago for a fun weekend.  We thought we'd have a nice little bakery tour.  This was one of our stops.  First, there's NO WHERE to park.  I drove around for maybe 8 minutes looking for parking.  Finally I parked illegally and ran in.   We ordered a napolean, a variety of italian cookies (7 different varieties) and a long puff pastry thing with custard inside and chocolate on top.  Just to be clear - they make their own breads and pizzas.   Napolean: I can GUARANTEE that this was bought (by them) premade and cut in the store.  It was truly AWFUL.  Grocery stores sell better.  It had custard in the layers.  The entire thing tasted of the chemical preservative that was used.  Ugh.  Two bites and in the trash it went. The cookies - again, clearly premade and dolled up.  We had one that was a butter cookie with caramel and chocolate icing.  The best of the lot.  The plain macaroon - shockingly dry and premade.  Lemon knot - made in house and DRY AS A BONE.  Maybe that was the goal.  I don't know.  It wasn't good.  We had the chocolate crescent and the powdered crescent.  Clearly the same cookie - premade and dolled up to be marginally different.  Blah and not remarkable in any way. The long cream puff pastry thing was gross.  Ganache should get to the point where you can touch it and it not stick to you.  This is an oil based premade chocolate icing.  As such it never crusts and stays sticky and messy.  The puff pastry thing was okay.  The custard inside those was clearly purchased, not made in the bakery. In the end, they had some things that were likely made in the store - the cannoli, the bread, the pizzas.  We were just wanting to try some nice bakeries in Chicago.  The counter girls yell at you.  Not pleasant.  It was truly awful and not worth the money.  I would NEVER recommend this place.

I can't believe no one mentioned the similarity to 'Cammareri Bros. Bakery' of Brooklyn from 1987 chick flick Moonstruck w/ Cher and Nicholas Cage (great movie!).  I half expect Ronny to come up from a coal fired hearth in the basement. And the girls who work the counter remind me of their counterparts in the movie too! Moonstruck aside this place bakes phenomenally well! I  am writing because I really love their crusty sour dough bread & I love their other breads which they will slice. I also love their heated pan pizza slices & really love their new foray into sandwiches - taste great, made quickly, cheaper than Bari next door and less of a line! And D'amato's has an enclosed patio with tables! I also love, love the cannoli!
Pizza by the slice is really good - just be sure they heat it up. Also, got a large box of assorted cookies and they were all delicious. I would like to try more sandwiches there.

Favorite bread place and it happens to be in my neighborhood.  They sell pizza dough - $2/lb I think, and it's great for making calzones or your favorite 'za.  Great selection of italian pastries and cookies.  Head next door to Bari for a sub made on their bread.  Yum!  Cash only

This place just gets better and better.Great bread,good bakery pizza and now great sandwiches.It's starting to become what I miss so much growing up near Freddy's on 16th.Real Italian style bakery and sandwiches.I have not tried their pasta yet, but it won't be long.Great service and a huge selection of baked goods.

ive never actually set foot inside d'amatos...id prob get myself in trouble if i did...but their tomato bread is my absolute favorite im tellin u man...i have to contain my excitement every time i pick some up otherwise id devour it by the time i got home

I love this bakery... I go in for all sorts of things, but my favorites are the pizza bread like thingies for lunch and the kolaches (yes, better than any polish bakery I've found).  The prices are fair, but they don't take credit cards, so I'm knocking them down to four stars.  Parking can be an issue.

absolutely fantastic find! I have never been to Italy, but its exactly what I expect a bakery in Italy to be like. Pizza is legit, cannoli's are delicious, bread is fantastic. And its cheap. totally worth stopping in.

What a gem! If you ever hope to go to a cute and authentic Italian bakery, come here and it will live up to everything! We parked right out front on a Friday afternoon, put 20 minutes on the meter and quickly realized it would take 20 minutes just to pick out what sweet treat we wanted. The staff was wonderful, patient and helpful as we asked a million questions about the desserts. It is a small place with seating for about three, everyone besides my friend and I seemed to be picking up pizza and treats to go. Their outdoor patio would have added to the already wonderful experience, but it was not open since it was during a heat wave. One should try their cannoli, tiramisu or some other traditional Italian dessert, but I found myself ordering a double layer cake, with pastry cream and topped with ganache. Yum. My friend tried the cannoli, tiramisu and their traditional Sicilian pizza. We have made a pact to come back many more times before we leave as we are just here for the summer. Unfortunately, it is a bit of a trip from Evanston...but well worth it.  I have not tried any of their bread, but I can not imagine that it would dissapoint.
Delicious Italian bread. Be careful not to eat too much (it's so good). Don't like that they only take cash.
Cooookie!  I really do love the cookies here.  I recently introduced a new coworker to them and she was hooked immediately.  Yum is the word.

It's all about the bread. If I'm cooking something that requires a compliment of amazing bread, there's no place other than D'amatos.  Their loaves are crusty on the outside, soft on the inside and so fresh. Love.

This is such a great, authentic Italian bakery.  Everyday they have many homemade breads, desserts, pizzas, and now they even make lattes to order.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!  Although they are very busy during the lunch hour, so I'd recommend coming before or after that time.

I don't have much of a sweet tooth but do have a thing for biscotti.  All the biscottie are done well here, but sesame is by far my favorite.  They also offer house-made pizza, suppli and focaccia as well as other breads.  The pizza is tasty but I can only eat a slice or 2 since it tends to be a bit on the greasy side.

One of the reasons I love living in Chicago is the fact that these little family gems with a true specialty and pride in their goods exist. The flat pizzas, traditional pizzas, cookies, breads... everything is so beautiful, delicious and made with love. Once you try it you will hard pressed to find any italian baked goods that are better. And the service is always great.

Lucky me...I found D'amato's one sunny afternoon walking to nowhere.  The smell hit me first and I couldn't resist stepping in.  I was walking so I didn't want to carry a lot of stuff but there are a few chairs there - so maybe next time.  I ordered two cannoli - one dipped in chocolate  Cannolis are my absolute favorite dessert  - and these are the very best I've ever had - the perfect crunch, a ton of pistachios, the filling is perfection!! - soooo creamy and not too sweet. I can not wait to go back with a giant bag - can't wait to try the take home dinners - stromboli, lasagna etc.. and MORE cannolis!!!  Fantastic!

This pizza is utterly fantastic no doubt. But you also need to try the arancini. They are balls of rice that are stuffed with goodness. Some had mushrooms, some meat, another red pepper, one with peas & carrot, and my favorite, spinach & ricotta, and only 2 bucks. You will not be disappointed.

A+ Pastries: -sliders (blueberry, etc) B Pastries:  -Chocolate cannoli: best cannoli I've ever had but then again I'm not a cannoli person C Pastries: -Chocolate eclair: pastry had a weird texture, wouldn't get again Lots of other stuff looked delicious but at $2/$3 per pastry I didn't want to go over budget and try everything at once. They also have freshly baked bread and all kinds of baked pasta that you can take home (lasagna etc).

This is the BEST Italian-American bakery that I've been to. I've been here twice now and the first time I came for the pizza, the second time I came to order 2 dozen canolies for work. Starting with the pizza, it is done in the true Italian pizza-by-the-slice style with nice puffy dough, cut into squares, and the even ask you if you want it warmed up. The flavor packed into these pizzas is superb, the sauce is amazing and the cheese is the real thing. This is easily my favorite true pizza slice joint.  Moving on to the canolies, these things are THE DANK! The ricotta filling is massaged perfectly with the appropriate amount of sugar and spices. The shells are also perfectly baked, not too hard yet not overly soft and spongy. They're a real treat and must have anytime you visit.  Overall this is a remarkable joint and for anyone who visit the city, it's an absolute must.

6:22 AM on Christmas Eve, and this place is bumpin'.  Rightfully so, let me tell you...  The assortment of things on offer here is enough to bring you back a few times without being well-versed on all that they offer. I came in for a couple of loaves of crusty, chewy bread that is going to go along with tonight's dinner.  Others were also there for the loaves, but included in their orders things like cookies, canolies, whole pizzas, pizza slices (square cut out of a Roman-style sheet tray), demi-loaves, buns and beautifully crafted pastry cakes. Me being the novice, not having my jolt of coffee yet to sort my head straight, and remembering only to bring just enough cash to cover what I was really there for held me back from adding to my own order.  Probably better off that way, because for $9.00 I came home with a 1 Pound Vienna loaf and two Half-French loaves that look, smell, and maybe most importantly at a time when you are buying bread- FEEL perfect. Cash only, so come prepared.

4.5 stars For some reason, I wanted cannoli. This is weird because I have only consumed cannoli once in my life, and that was while I was on vacay in NYC. It wasn't all that great, but I told myself that I would give it another go since everyone raves about how great it's supposed to be, and I wanted something not as heavy as a cupcake for dessert. Prior Yelp reviews led me here (plus, my goal for the month of December is to support local businesses and establishments only). Upon entering the store, it smelled great! There were lots of different breads, pastries, and focaccia (which I was going to get after reading the review of "Erin N.", but due to another business I wanted to try for lunch being directly next door--Bari--decided to hold off until the next visit). I ordered a chocolate covered for $1.80, and man was it good and sweet! The one I had in NYC didn't compare to this one at all! I intensely fought with my inner foodie to go back and purchase/eat another one that same day. If you want something different besides standing in line for a cupcake or froyo, head here folks. Everything was reasonably priced, and it's a local establishment that deserves your business!
Best bread I've ever had.  Also can't leave without a slice of pizza and a cherry slice.  I still haven't found anything here I don't like, and I don't think I ever will.

Amazing bakery! The canollis are phenomenal with that signature bright green color. We always get dough for our pizzas here at only $2/lb its a steal!! If we're in the neighborhood we'll stop in for a hearty slice of their pizza for about $2.50-$3.50 depending on what toppings you choose (pepperoni, cheese, sausage, or veggie which are all amazing).  But be warned- CASH ONLY!!!!

I just inhaled an artichoke heart and black olive focaccia bread pizza, almond biscotti and chocolate covered turtle cookie like I've never eaten before. I may have shared, but definitely didn't want to. Everything is fresh and delicious. And you will experience symptoms of A.D.D when trying to finalize an order. Pretty sure the girl who helped me lost patience with my indecision, but I don't care. It was worth it. This is definitely happening again, to the dismay of my waist line.

The bread is good, to be sure. The cannoli alright. But few of the cookies resemble anything I've seen or tasted in a proper Italian bakery. No pignoli cookies? Nope. And when I asked for them, I was told to call a day ahead to request them. And rather rudely, at that. Not impressed.

This place saved me...I was picking up some fresh Italian bread for my pasta party, and decided after all the rave reviews that I needed to try the additional items mentioned.  So, I got the last focaccia bread and 2 regular and 2 chocolate cannolis.  I was short $1.60 since they take cash only.  Embarrassed, I had to ask the girl helping me to take back a cannoli.  She said not to worry about it, and I am so grateful.  The Italian bread, focaccia, and the cannolis were delicious!  I am not sure how to thank the girl and show my appreciation for this place.

Best bread in Chicago.  Hands down!  Foccacia = sex in my mouth. The girl who works there with the tattoos (Paula, I think?) rules!  Very educational and courteous.  Don't know how much she gets paid or what her employee status is, but she went out of her way to make recommendations and indulged me a little in the amazing bread making process. Will be a repeat customer.

FRESH, FRESH, FRESH! Yes, that's right folks freshly baked breads, pizza, foccacia, cannoli, pastries, tiramisu, tarts and then some. Need I say more? Yes? Ok the staff is amazingly friendly too! Couldn't be happier than to have this place a hop, skip and a jump away. :)

First it was $5 cupcakes. Then it was $5 doughnuts. Now people are queued up for blocks to drop $5 on of all things froyo. When will return to the good old fashioned values of our grandparents' generation and start finding delicious treats at reasonable prices. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you D'amato's Bakery. After driving past this place at least 100 times, I finally worked up the nerve to hit up D'amato's for some cannoli. I have to say I was thoroughly impressed. This bakery is old school. They have the old timey depression-era cash register and it's cash only so you know this is gonna be some good old fashioned, questionably book-keeped baked goods. This bakery smells amazing and at 9:30am it was already hopping. I opted for some cannolis, both the regular and chocolate, and they were fantastic and relatively cheap too! They also had a slew of cookies, pastries, pizzas, breads, it was awesome. Parking can be a hassle, but it was well worth it. I will definitely be back to sample more of the baked goods here. Here's hoping cheap cannolis become the $5 cupcake of 2012.

Coal burning oven...enough said!!! The bread here is amazing...one of the best loaves you can find in the city. Bari next door also uses the bread for there amazing sub sandwiches...it does not get any fresher then that. Traditional Italian cookies and Cannoli's are good.  Also try the Sicilian Pizza Bread. They have made some improvements here.  Personally I liked it old looking.  Now when you walk in you feel like you might be in a fancy coffee shop. Window tables were added, so you can see people eating and drinking coffee in the window.  I think it draws more people in...good for them but bad for me. They have also just added an outdoor patio (Sept 2011)...just in time for the cold weather...sit out here and your coffee becomes iced right before your eyes.  I am going to wait until summer. Also, if you are lucky you can see the coal delivery...it is kind of fun...reminds me of the old days when coal powered everything from trains to furnaces...it is like a piece of history.

While visiting Chicago, I tried my luck to see if I could find some authentic cannoli's here. Yelp led me to D'amato's, I'm glad it did.  I was planning on just buying 1 cannoli (I've literally eaten my way through this city) However, the gorgeous spread of treats were too inticing. I did limit myself though, bought a bag of various cookies - I'm excited to try the chocolate dipped almond biscotti tmrw morning! And a mini foccacia for $1!  My total came out to a little over $5 for so many treats!  We ate the cannoli right when we got in the car, legit. Everything I'm going to save after we get back to Houston =)

For our wedding we were going for something different for our cake, D'amato's really out did themselves!  We had an envisioned mini cakes for our guests to choose the cake of their choice, rather than have one option.   We had cannoli, chocolate, strawberry, tiramisu, and carrot mini cakes.  The pictures do not do them justice, you can see what they all really looked like on TLC Four Weddings, airing in September 2011.  They were so fresh and amazing our guest are still talking about them!  We also had a large cannoli's with mini cannoli's inside too...  Last but not least our wedding night ended with our guest feasting on fresh focaccia bread, it was the best way to send everyone home.

The savory items looked amazing, diverse, and delicious. Sadly, I'd already had lunch so I stuck with the sweets. The butter cookies are pretty plain and kind of what you'd expect - not at all bad, but not so exciting. Next time I'd definitely try the pizzas and other savory stuff.

Oh how those pistachio cookies haunt my dreams. I LOVE them. I want to marry them. A whole tray full of them. All of the fruit filled cookies made me happy too. The red ones could be my bridesmaids. An orange one could be the flower girl. And the biscotti could be the groomsmen.

What do you do when you need 500 cookies in less than a week and you need them delivered? Call D'amato's! My work was hosting an event and we needed an assortment of cookies. And not just any cookies, but cookies from an Italian bakery since we are an Italian company. Called with only 5 days till the event and it was no problem. They even delivered for free and were on time too. The cookies were very nice looking and they sent us probably 15 different types. Everyone raved over them and couldn't eat just one! Some of the best cookies I've had! I even asked them to call me the day before the event with the total price and they did. The original lady who took my order was very friendly on the phone, though some of their other employees could use a lesson in customer service.  They price per pound and don't take credit cards.

I think people must love the charm of an old school bakery so much that they have forgotten to taste the food.  I have had their focaccia, italian bread, and kolackies.  All were very bland and the italian bread was extremely crumbly and stale.  I like the idea of this place, just wish their product was better.

CASH ONLY!~ I found this place by accident while venturing Chicago for the first time. I know nothing about Italian baked goods and so I just asked the Italian mom working the front to put together a box for me. One of my favorite items she put in the box was this lemon cookie with frosting. For 11 dollars worth of cookies, I definetly got my moneys worth. Aside from the cookies, I also purchased two small personal size pizzas. They also have other bread and baked goods that worth checking out.

I'm Italian, and I come from a family of Italian bakers, so I know good Italian baked goods - and this place has 'em! Their cannoli (fresh, crunchy shells and sweet, creamy filling), Italian wedding cookies, and focaccia are SUPERB. Their assorted cookies are also delicious, albeit not as outstanding as the aforementioned items.  The Sicilian slices are delicious and authentic, just like Grandma used to make! Their prices are unbelievably affordable, which makes their sweets and breads all the more delightful.

Awesome Italian bakery.  Excellent focaccia and pizzas,  and tons of varieties of Italian cookies (raspberry jam filled dipped in chocolate, and nutella filled were faves).   Next time will try some bread - it all looked wonderful. Super friendly service and a great neighborhood spot. Cash only!

It was Fat Tuesday and I had already gorged on Paczki in the office. But I had a hard day, the weather was nice, so I decided to walk up Grand Ave. and check out some shops before catching my bus. D'amato's is known for their cannoli and it was Fat Tuesday... Italian wedding cookies, cannoli, arancini, tomato breads and pizza by the slice. And with excellent service, D'amato's really has it covered.  I got two slices of the cold pizza to go, which they offered to warm up for me. The Pizza was excellent. I also got the Chocolate covered cannoli and a standard cannoli (don't make me say Fat Tuesday again) and it was some of the BEST CANNOLI  I've ever tasted. They may even have the North End of Boston beat!
Best cannoli (chocolate dipped) and granny slices of pizza I know of.

I come to the D'Amato's Yelp page every now and again, mostly to look to see if some deranged Yelper has finally decided to give D'Amato's one star. The fact that some have given it only two stars is a testament that the road to edgy hipness, is ridden with the corpses of "small plate" foodies who typed the poor review while drinking a can of the the "old man's hip beer of the month"  listening to B-sides of 45's by bands no one else will ever hear of and wishing D'Amato's was in a really shitty neighborhood because that might earn it one more star, but I digress. This is as old school as they come, and it should never change. Not for those who remember it from thirty years ago and have a nostalgic fondness from days gone by from their youth. No, this is from the file; "they don't make 'em like they used to" and you can tell in every bite, and that's where it counts. The bread is the star here, made a couple of times a day (no, you aren't getting day old "yesterday bread.") Hit your timing just right and they will hand you a loaf that is still warm. The long French loaf is king. This is what they make the subs on next door at Bari. Perfect crunch on the outside and soft on the inside (it is important to note, in Bari reviews, some complaining that the bread is "(whine . . .) too hard"  and those people need to revert back to their mommy's PB&Js that were made with the crusts removed and expertly cut into triangles, "just the way you like them, honey.") And while the bread may be king, the sweets are the noble queen. Try and make it home without popping out a canolli for the ride. Or just challenge yourself to eat only half of an apple or cherry slice. Need to bring some snacks for a meeting at work? Have them fill you a box of a pound or two of assorted cookies, but only if you can handle the hero worship of your co-workers that will follow. And a word or two of advice: Do not, and I repeat DO NOT go there hungry. The smell alone will cripple you, rendering you defenseless from spending every nickle in your pocket (Yes, it's cash only. Get over it . . .) after perusing the glass cases on each side of the room. And lastly to address other reviews that have found the front counter staff unfriendly; get over yourself ! I have found not a soul there without a smile on their face, who wasn't friendly, asked how I was, chatted about what I might be cooking and generally, beyond pleasant. Perhaps those that thought otherwise, might consider not wearing their "Born To Scowl" t-shirt, and hire a life coach, to teach them all the things that mommy and daddy didn't, by example or otherwise, about being courteous, pleasant, polite and to not treat people like they are your servants. A little decorum goes a long way. You reap what you sow . . .

EVERY time I drive down Grand, I always want to stop here.  Every. Single. Time.   I usually stick to the Sicilian slices. I like inside b/c I like them cheesy, hubs likes the outside corner pieces b/c he likes the caramalization of the crust.  They are priced pretty awesomely, about $2 a slice (more for toppings) and they are really freakin' fantastic. When I do have a taste for something else, I get the round pizza on the focaccia bread, which are equally delish, but more filling. Every pizzaish thing I've had here has been yum. Wait, also, you NEED to get the chocolate dipped cookies with the raspberry filling. They are amaaahhhhzzzing.

Great Italian Bakery... I'm pretty sure the reason Bari Subs are so popular is because they use D'amatos bread!! They're are also known for their Pizza which is sold by slice/pan and usually have like 8 varieties daily. It's very good/lots of flavor! Many other Baked Goods to choose from---Tiramisu/Cannoli's/Cookies/Brownies, etc. A true "Old World" Bakery and I can honestly say it's "Cheap" for this day and age! GTFJD

Old world Italian service bring you down to earth... not for your average Lincoln Parker if you don't like real folks that tell you like it is. Pizza is awesome as a meal or snack. Focaccia is made fresh and goes bad if you don't eat it in two days -- no preservatives with fresh ingredients made fresh daily and a couple of times on the weekend. Fresh breads baked same day -- again meant to eat quckly with no preservatives. Cannoli's and a variety of other cookies to bring as a gift to folks -- I do it often. They recently had a facelift and makes the place look a bit more modern and not so neglected.  The only have like 2 stools by the window so don't expect to have a great dine in experience... we walk over to get stuff to take back or eat in our cars.  May need to park a block over on peak hours. Just another reason that I love the neighborhood.

one of the best Italian bakeries in the Chicago land area. Their bread is so fresh and is very inexpensive. Iwould recomend their homemade pizza slices, their lemon cookies, and their canolies. The bakery it very small and it is always crowded. but the wait is not long at all.

Been here 4 or 5 times now.  Seems like freshness and quality of ingredients is a real problem for this place.  The loaf of white bread they sold me today was definitely not baked today.  Also, beware cheese and cream-based fillings.

Me: "I'm starving, what should I get" Them: "You hungry, try some of da' foca'ch" Me: "I'm not sure, it looks carby" Them: "Just try da' foca'ch, it's good take it" Me: "Oh what the hell!" You certainly get the authentic thing when you come to D'amato's.  This is a wonderful little Italian bakery, and it's a gold mine for "da foca'ch" and many other pastries and goodies. The fumes of fresh baked cookies, cannoli, and breads are full bodied and strike your nose the second you enter.  The inside is small but to the point.  All the food you want to grab is within arms reach (dangerous for us with an empty stomach) and there is a wonderful vintage hand operated cash register where your total is churned into.   I've been here a few times now, and can say for a fact that they really have "da foca'ch" nailed down.  Last night I had some pizza before the bulls game.  I tried two variations of vegetable supreme, and one pita shaped margherita pizza.  The veggie supremes were wrapped in a white sheet, and I could see the grease accumulating.  Good luck to my heart!  The slices were filling to say the least, as the two veggies both had the focaccia base.  They had a wonderful taste, however I wish they were heated up.  I went in late, and they were taken straight from the pizza tray an wrapped.  Fresh I could imagine these tasting great. We sat and ate at the window sill before the bulls game, and enjoyed the atmosphere.  Overall good food, service and environment.  I put health aside for the night so that I could try something different. This is a wonderful little spot, and I'll be back.
Good bread. Great pastries. The staff leaves something to be desired.

Luv this place and always leave with Cannolis when I visit. It's usually busy but worth the wait. Inexpensive and the quality is second to none. Authentic Italian Bakery.  Make it a point to stop in. They take cash only and the last time I went there the closest ATM was a few doors down.

I remember, as a kid, my dad working on the near south side.  One thing we would always look forward to would be when he would bring home a tray of the bakery pizza from D'amato's.  So many years have passed since those days.  Sad, I know. Well, recently, I decided to refresh my memory.  I was having a Christmas party and needed something else to add to the menu.  So, I got a couple trays of the bakery pizza.  By the time I got home, I had succumbed to the temptation of that delicious, delicious bakery pizza.  So worth it and just how I remembered it.   Another beautiful thing about D'amato's are their zeppoli.  They are the perfect ending to any St. Joseph's Day meal (if you aren't going to a St. Joseph's Table) The next time I go in, I am stocking up on those cookies!

The owner or baker whatever he was ... The best dude I've ever met. Our order was screwed up and he came over no yelling just joked with us and helped make it right and was all around hilarious. Best experience ever!  The bread, focaccia... Everything tastes like pure perfection!  Prices what!  I bought like seven things and it totaled less the ten dollars.  I'm going back all the time!!!

Some of the best foccacia around. Cannoli's to die for. Delicious pizza slices on sheet pans that they'll heat up for you at the store or you can take home (in the paper bag that gets all oily) and heat up there. Great breads and one of the best apple strudels you can find in Chicago. I try to make a point of visiting whenever I'm in the city - it's a real treat.  Great prices too.

We recently got married on 10/23/10.  Being Italian, we thought it would be fun to give Italian cookies as a wedding favor.  We have been going to D'Amato's for years so we thought of them right away.  As always, the cookies were delicious and all of the guests loved them.  The only negative was that D'Amato's charged us an extra packaging fee to put the cookies in our little favor boxes.  Given that the cookies were pricey it would have been nice to not have had this fee charged.  But overall we were very happy with the service and the cookies!
I always stop here for the cookies and cannolis after I get a sub next door at Bari.  Always good.  Street parking but it's OK to double park around the corner for a few minutes on the side street.

The pizza slices here are to die for and the best I've had this year. I want to try every kind of bread they have and all of the wonderful treats. You can also buy pizza dough to make at home and the cannoli here are really a beautiful sight. Right now they are operating out of a building across the street from the regular location. Really friendly staff - wonderful place!
I"m addicted to buying fresh bread from here because it's cheap and I can't buy it straight from the gonnella factory.

Here's an awesome authentic Italian bakery that actually smells wonderful inside... Like a real bakery!   Wonderful Italian and French bread, homemade pan pizza, cookie and wonderful canoli.  I ordered a big canoli stuffed with little canolis inside for Christmas and it was well received. They are remodeling their store but part of the nostalgic image here is the antiquity of the place.  Hopefully, they will keep some of it's charm and nostalgia with their dated late 1950's cash register. Excellent and well worth a visit.
Everything here is amazing and the staff is very friendly! My favorites are the cannolis and pizza. Prices are amazing!

Due to construction, they are temporarily located across the street.  Parking is still tough around there, but you can find plenty of spaces down on Hubbard.    They have plenty of options and it's all freshly made right there.  The quality is unsurpassed.  They have regular and chocolate covered cannolis.  There is a wide variety of focaccia that you can tell was just baked.  There are plenty of breads to choose from.  One of the weaknesses is if you are unfamiliar with anything, you'll have to constantly ask the staff for names, prices, and descriptions.  The place is pretty active so you'll be holding people up if you do so.  There are desserts in different counters and locations so make sure you scan where everything is so you don't miss something!

D'Amato's Bakery is great!  The round Italian bread is to die for (I dip it in olive oil with garlic) and the cookies are like sunshine on a cloudy day.  Can't go wrong with these masters of baked goods!
This little bakery makes the best breadsticks I've ever had! Some of my out-of-town guests insist on a stop at this bakery before/after stocking up at Blommer's Chocolate.

Best cannoli I've had in years.  Equal to many people's favorite, Mike's Pastry in Boston.  Crispy shell, beautiful delicious filling, the chocolate had a great coating inside and out.  We had one of the foccacia pizzas - it was delicious as well.  We had a few of the cookies as well - all were really tasty.  This is a Chicago gem, I can't wait to go back.

Picked up 6 cannolis to try. I'm not a big fan of them, but these weren't too overly sweet, but still can only handle a few bites. If I'm in the area, I'll maybe try the other stuff out. Friendly service.

D'amato's is amazing. Here's why:  When I was younger, and punker, and more anti- establishment, I enjoyed dumpster diving. And late at night, I'd bike over to D'amatos, and peek inside the dumpster- to find these tiny foccacias that I'd "liberate", and take for lunch the next day. Looking back, that was gross. At the time, I thought I was very, very radical.  Years later, I got a real job, and  walked through the front doors of D'amatos for the first time. I bought an amazing slice of pizza, and a cookie decorated to look like Frankenstein. The pizza had a thick, light crust, and artichokes, and olives, and the like, with just a smattering of cheese. I love that pizza.  Go to D'amato's, through the front door, and get the pizza. I don't even like pizza...this is more than pizza....it's a masterpiece.
Just got a dozen of their Cannoli's.  YUM.  I'm going back for more.  Nuff said.
cannolis & sourdough loaves are fantastic.   smiles & friendly service are non-existent.   i keep going back, so you can guess what's important in my book...
mmm pizza bread, italian cookies.  You can go wrong at this place, they make it perfect! AND Bari is next door so grab a meatball sandwich while you are there!

The crunch of the cannoli shell was the first indicator that this was going to be an awesome cannoli. The ricotta, powdered sugar and chocolate chips were perfectly balanced, not too sweet, enough little nuggets of choclate yet smooth. The cannoli shell was crisp the whole way through, no hint of the all too often sogginess which accompanies too many cannolis. This is the best cannoli in the Chicago area and maybe even farther.  We also bought a long loaf of Italian bread which was supermarket quality. Maybe next time we'll try one of the rustic breads we spotted in the window on the way out.  However, the cannolis are perfecto and I will be back for those!
These have to be the best cannoli and chocolate cannoli in the city.   They are fresh, sweet and crispy.    They are also a great deal - $1.80 per

Cannoli, Cannoli, Cannoli!!! We were having an Italian themed dinner and I was in charge of bringing dessert.  I found this bakery on Yelp and decided to go after reading the good reviews.  Not disappointing at all. I picked up Cannolis and Tiramisu.  Everyone loved it!   Didn't try the bread though, that will be on my next visit

I love this place! Great bread and the pizza is unique. Its a nice change of pace from the usual chicago thin or thick pizza.  TWO CRITICISMS: 1)After you handle cash money all day, please , please use tongs or put on gloves when you touch my bread. 2) I live down the street and have been going here for years, never once have I gotten a friendly smile or a how are you. It always "what do you need and bye". I put up with it becasue the bread is so darn good.

Add me to the list of fans.  Been going here for years whenever I get into the neighborhood. The Italian bread...heaven. I could just eat the crust all day with some olive oil and grated parmesan. Its a meal in itself. Truly the best bread of its kind I've ever had (and I lived in NYC for five years, where its a point of pride to have "que panne".) And the sweets are top notch. If The Godfather had been filmed in Chicago, this is where Clemenza would have gone for cannolis - "leave the gun. Take the cannolis".  Go to the deli next door, Bari's, for nice sandwiches, pastas, and other Italian goodies.  D'Amato's - "fogett aboud it! Its da best!"

I have not had a chance to try much at this bakery.  The past few times I just a piece of the Italian bread and called it a day.  3 bucks cash only at their old register, done deal. The bread is soft and freshly made, much better than the stuff you would get at other nameless grocery stores.  I will have to come back and try more though...
Best Bread in Town.  You always end up buying more then you expect, so bring extra dough for the cannoli you know you need to have.

This is one of the many perks of living on Grand.  I miss it. My days off living in the neighborhood consisted of (at least,but not limited to): 2 slices of pizza (the best thick pan slices), 2 cuccidati (fig cookies), and a can of limonata.  I knew I was spoiled living 3 doors down... and I took advantage. I don't have much of a sweet tooth, so aside from the cuccidati I really only ate biscotti (anisette) which are great, but I can say that their cookies all look great and I'd back any of them.  The focaccia is a great runner up to the pizza, super nice and doughy.  Arancini... I could only handle 1 at a time, but they are amazing and super rich. On the weekends this place gets pretty busy.  Between Bari and D'amato's the chaos of double parking out front is pretty intense... but its definitely a sign they're doing something right. Always friendly service even before I made a day-off-ritual of coming in.  Order a pound or 2 of cookies for the holidays and you'll be a champion with your family. T'amu D'amato's.  *Say hi to Joe... If he's standing out on grand just east of bari.

Every time I stop at Bari Foods for Italian lunch meats, I always stop here afterwards to get good Italian bread.  It's fresh and I love the way the bakery smells when you walk in.  Prices are reasonable for fresh baked bread.  I have only gotten their rolls but their other offerings look amazing.  One day soon I will have to expand my horizon with other delicious baked goods.
I heart D'amato's Cannolis. I heart them so much that they may even replace a cake at my wedding... someday. Until then, they go really well with our big, Italian Sunday dinners.
Best bread in the city.  The crust is probably the best I've had anywhere. The cookies & canoni aren't too bad, either.

I love this place. It is such a pleasure when you smell the freshly baked bread they do every night. There are people driving from the suburbs just to buy their bread! Lucky us the people living in the neighborhood! In a nut shell: great bread, great cookies, their focacia bread is unbelievable (especially the thin one). During the summer they have some good gellato too, try it, you will not be disappointed!

When I worked over near juvenile court my co-workers and I would eat the most delicious sandwich made at this place with focaccia bread and italian meats and cheeses.  Do they still sell them?  If so I will take a drive.  The best!

I've been baking homemade bread for almost a year now.  That's 12 months of slowly tweaking my recipe between bread, wheat and rye flours all while continually feeding my "b*tch"; what Anthony Bourdain calls a homemade sourdough starter.  I've even purchased clay bakers in an effort to get that crusty crust bread lovers strive for.  It took some time but I finally found my inspiration: D'amato's Bakery. This place isn't new, it's not well lit at night and it's cash only.  The register looks like something out of a 1940's war movie where the numbers don't even line up properly.  I love it.  And don't forget to bring that Italian-American accent with you when stepping through the door.  The sourdough bread has a crust so thick it has it's own crust.  And the flavor can't be beat.  Do yourself a favor and swing by Bari Foods next door to pick up some cold cuts or pasta and finish your trip with a visit to D'amato's Bakery.  You won't ever buy another kind of bread again.

I went here for lunch today and it was pretty good.  I work right down the block but I hadn't managed to stop by yet... My boss told me they have only still running coal-fired oven in the city of Chicago. I had the focaccia with olives, artichoke hearts, and onions.  It was pretty good reheated and only $4.  The artichoke hearts served here for once didn't taste like they were from a can (and if they were, I wanna know what it was!). Ill be going back soon...

Walked into this place for the 1st time ever. I'm such a sucker for sweets. This small enchanting place offered me some sweets for my Lazy Sunday.  I bought a 1lb of cookies. I know I know it seems like a lot but when you buy the huge cookies not so much. I had one of the crescent cookies...it was delicious. I also ordered some of their chocolate double cookies and I couldn't believe how it melted in your mouth.  Customer service was great. Will be going back to try some of their other baked goods.

I never remember what I get from here.  Ok, ok, I always get something different and I just want it to be "light and fluffy and delicious".  We always go to Bari's and then head here for some pastries and I'm never let down.  Ever.  Even when I forget to put my dessert in the fridge (pretty much anything I eat has to be cold)........but D'amato's is so good, I'll eat my dessert at room temp! Remember to bring cash!

World Class stuff - EVERYTHING. Margarita pizza/focaccia - mornings fresh - Wow BEST canoli I EVER had - period. Breads are wonderful - just stay away from the "white" reg bread - nothing special there. LOVE this place!
Fabulous cookies! Even though they went up in price per pound, they are sooo good and tender.

Mmm, arancini. I'm not a big fan of spinach, but they do have one without it. It's just rice and cheese in a delicious ball of fried dough. MMM. I used to work in the loop. Sometimes, I would get a ride and we would pass by here. I'm really glad I was able to try it one day, because everything here is delicious. They have gelato, and I'm pretty sure they have different flavors each day. Yummy. The pizza breads and foccacias are fantastic. D'amato's cookies are not only adorable, they are quite delicious as well. I honestly don't think I have tried something here that I didn't like. Go try it now.

Some of the best freshly made Italian bread.  Many sizes, all Italian, all $3.  Love it.  The arancinis are also pretty amazing.  But I have this horrible habit of eating them on the way home, usually when they're cold... I haven't tried their desserts, but I assume if their bread is great, so must be the desserts.  Oh, and it's cash only.
Everything is great from here. Especially their canollis and sasuage pizza bread.yummy! Cash Only!
Fantastic bakery. Used to make the bagel sized "pizza bread" mandatory breakfast
Best cannoli I've had in Chicago!  Everything I've had from this bakery has been amazing, and the cash register is very cool.

From the old as shit cash register, to the racks filled with crusty bread and cookies by the pound, to the sassy Italian women working behind the counter, this place has character. You just don't see newer places like this, and I realize that this makes me sound old ("they just don't make them like they used to"), but really and truly, I'm looking forward to the day that I can hike up my pants to my chest, walk around with a cane, and randomly call people things like 'sonny', and 'whippersnapper'.  I imagine that old age will allow me to get away with indiscretions I've only dreamed of so far and I can only hope that D'amatos' will still be there to provide me my damn foccaca with olives. Progress schmagress.

If you're at Bari foods, definitely stop by here for some snacks and canolli. I looked at something weird (now I know as arancini), asked what was in it, and they gave it to me. $2. Fried dough filled with rice, spinach, cheese. Yum! I love places like these.

Sheet pizza...YUM  "One slice pepperoni and one slice zaaasage please.  Warm it up?  No thanks...i live right down the street." WIsh they had some wheat breads.  The french and italian bread is delicious...but is more of a special occasion bread for me.   Sweets, foccacia and arancini is also delicious! Real italian bakery for sure
Fantastic Breads!  Old School, family run bakery for more than 45 years.  One of two Coal Fired Oven Bakeries left  in Chicago. Try the Pizza Bread, cookies and cannolis.  Not to disappoint!

D'amato's bakery is a family run italian bakery located in the noble square neighborhood.  All of the breads are baked in a coal fired oven giving them an extraordinary texture and consistency.  The breads in general have a hard cracker like crust and a very delicate center, which separates D'amato's from other neighborhood bakeries.  Along with the breads is a sparse menu featuring pizza by the slice, an array of cookie pastries, cannoli, and top quality focaccia. They recently added gelato to the menu as well.  The product is always priced fairly and is a real treat to the palate!

Feels like a neighborhood institution when you walk in, and you know it deserves to be once you bite into what you decided to try.  I've had their classic Italian not-too-sweet butter cookies in all shapes and sizes and with different kinds of frostings and embellishments, and they're all good.  My roommate swears by the U-shaped sandwich cookies.  I've also tried their basic whole wheat and Italian white breadloaves, and while both are good, the delicate white bread is addictive.  They also have a cool antique cash register.

I really like their focaccia! The bottom of the crust is kind of crunchy, and I love love love it. The folks who work here are really nice and their bread is cheap. I have a lot of respect for mom and pop bakeries, and this is one of my favorites.

I don't buy a whole lot of bread, but I am HOOKED on their spinach aranchinis (rice balls).   I swear I could live on those things.  So if you like a good vegetarian aranchini, I gaurantee you will not be disappointed. I can't speak for the meat ones, haven't tried them.  Oh, did I also mention D'amato's has gelato?  I disagree with what one reviewer said about parking -- just look on the side streets, not on Grand itself.  Oh, and if you're driving here - watch out for the cop with the speed radar hidden behind the sign  at the "marathon" gas station.

This is the ONLY Italian bakery I will go out of my way to drive to.   Fresh, inexpensive and a GREAT selection of things!  I'm talking all sorts of breads and rolls, 6 types of foccacia, arancini (2 types!), cannoli, cookies, pastries, cake and of course sheet pizza.  I just bought a baguette that is literally 4 feet long and I think I paid like 2 or 3 dollars for it.  Everything I have ever ordered has been excellent. You can walk in off the street or pre-order.  I would recommend the latter if you need a certain amount, flavour,  etc.as  I have been there just as they have run out of something I wanted.  Oh yeah, bring cash, they dont take credit cards!  Independent businesses rock and I am so glad to support this one!

Try one of their mini tomato breads, and you will be HOOKED.  The combination of bread, tomato and italian spices are sooo good, and you can taste the freshness of all the ingredients!! I will definitely have to go in and try their Italian cookies and pizzas. mmm... cookies :)

1st BRING CASH! They don't take any cards! Also parking really stinks. I've been looking for good Italian cookies like my mom would get when I was a kid. I've tried so many bad cookies in the last 6 months but I found some spectacular cookies here and at a good price. I brought them to a friends house for dinner...I ended up bring home the box. So good! I'll have to come back with more cash to try the bread and cannoli. I'll definitely be back soon!

I have been coming to this place for years!  way before it was known.......it was just the local italian bakery my dad took us too to pick up Italian bread.......tomato bread and the pizza bread!   It's awesome!   The tomato bread is out of this world.........you can buy the big one or the mini's!  The pizza.......isn't the cheapest........but it is great!  I have family and friends who come to town and ask if we can go pick up some of that "pizza bread".   The bread itself is delicious........nice hard crust.....makes great sandwiches and better yet........TOAST!   if you are in the area, stop in and check it out!

So one of my fondest memories from growing up was going into a small Italian bakery by our house in Mamaroneck, NY and buying fresh out of the oven rolls for a quarter.  It was always a special treat for me walking home from school.   So my mom decides that she needs me to find some Panettone to bring east for Christmas.  I begin the hunt for this elusive bread and find myself on the west side of the river at D'amato's.  Immediately when I walk in I have a rush of childhood memories and feel like I am back in that bakery again in NY. We ended up with the panettone as well as some yummy cookies to tie us over until then.  Everything was great and I walked out of there with a ton of stuff for less then $20.  I wold have bought some more BUT they only take cash so I had to stay within the boundaries of what was in my pocket. All in all, mom will be happy I found the panettone, I got some cookies, and I got to try a new place and find a piece of my childhood again. PS- the next day I saw some Panettone in Dominick's but I would not have traded my time at D'amato's for anything.

The perfect Bari companion.  Stop in here and grab a tasty canoli for dessert after you get your Bari italian sub and before you head back to your triple parked car.  The sheet pizza on top of the counter is classic as well.  Dee-lish as Retched Rachel would say.  Seriously though, it's pretty damn good for pizza made in Chicago.   I like their sub rolls, obviously, and they have lots of other tasty baked goods.  Try them all.  If you're dying for a French-style baguette this isn't the place.  But it's an Italian bakery so you already knew that.

Two words - chocolate cannolis. Cannolis dipped in chocolate. So incredibly sweet that all I need is one or two bites and I'm good for the rest of the month.  The tiramisu could be more. I like whip cream, but calling a fluff of whip cream and some soggy thin cake tiramisu, just doesn't do it for me. The foccacia bread is ok. Eat is fast! It always seems to spoil in a few days of sitting out. Nothing worse than going for a bite and seeing fungus on your bread. Traumatizing. The pizza is good. Rich, thick homemade pizza, not the cut-out cardboards of a fast food chain.

Their dark baguettes get 5 stars.  I love the thick crusted hearty Italian bread.  Maybe they just have a really awesome oven, because the dough doesn't seem all that complicated.  It's all about the crust.  Everything else is pretty good too; you won't be disappointed. Cash only!
For $1.50, this is the best cannoli in Chicago and they always taste fresh.  Knowing that they provide bread for numerous sub places around town, I can attest that this is also very high quality.

Secret pizza, secret dessert... As far as Italian bread carbs are concerned, if I am gonna eat 'em, I get my fix HERE.  First, this is one of the oldest Italian bakeries in the city.  One time I needed to get some bread, but they were closed.  The owner saw me and waved me in.  He brought me to the back and the smell was INCREDIBLE.  I'll tell ya, the only other places that have that kinda history are bakeries in Europe.  Making bread is as much an artform as it is a labor of love.  The wood tables, paddles and ovens were just amazing.  You could smell the care and the love this place has for bread, and we are lucky enough to be able to get it every day.   Back to the food:   BREAD - Remember, it's an Italian bread.  French bread sometimes is like cake, while Italian bread is firmer.  The regular loaf (like a baguette) has a crisp and chewy crust, and a soft center, great for garlic bread or bruschetta.  The sandwich loaf looks like a traditional bread, but has this amazing thin but crisp and chewy crust, with a perfect center.   SECRET PIZZA - Secret pizza, remember?  They make 3 (it used to be 2) kinds of pan pizza - cheese, sausage, pepperoni.  It's not ordinary by any means.  It's a rectangular, 1 inch thick slice, with a fragrant tomato gravy (dats right, REAL Italians call it dat) topped with a fontina, romano or something sharp.  The cheese is just right, and just below it, the tomato flavor is incredible.  If you're lucky enough to get a chewy edge, marron!  Order of favorite - cheese, sausage (pepperoni is too strong and takes away from everything).  We used to order this BY THE TRAY and it would be gone. They also have foccacia, arancini (stuffed rice balls), a new gelato bar, cookies, pizelle, rolls, etc. SECRET DESSERT - Man, I have no idea why they hide these things, but if you find em, GET EM.  Chery slices, apple slices, napoleons, huge chocolate eclairs, and, of course, cannoli.  It's like these were just like a little hobby they do back there, yet these are just so perfect, not too sweet, not to heavy, that you wonder why they don't make MORE. Slices - 2 x 4 x 4 inch pies with perfect fillings and vanilla icing.  One of each. Napoleons - thin pastry dough with vanilla custard and topped with vanilla icing.  I'll take TWO. Eclairs - 5 inch chocolate covered custard eclairs (that are FILLED, baby, no skimping here!).  I can only eat one, but I WANT 5. Cannoli - 4 inch delicate round cookie tubes filled with sweetened ricotta and chocolate chips, edged with nuts.  Always gimme TWO. Don't go hungry or you'll leave with a few bags. COST - Inexpensive CAVEATS - It small and parking is tough.  Be patient.  You will be rewarded.
Popped in here one day for lunch. Good Italian sub. Liked that it was a bakery, the bread was tasty. Wasn't awesome enough for me to crave going back.

Mmmm, my dad has been bringing me food here for years. Last week I finally went with him and got Italian Ice (light tasting), tomato bakery pizza (like one yelper said greasy, but it is good), and am not sure the name but this amazing bread they have that they cut into loaves and it tastes soo good toasted. Good expierance!
the smell of this place alone gets it 5 stars. yum.
Simply the BEST tomato bread in town. Susan,  the prettiest girl I work with,  just loves their pan pizza!

Bakery-style pizza you just can't beat and a selection of pasteries and bread as well.  The staff is super friendly, very italian.  The only downside is they don't take charge cards, so stock up on cash before you go.

My fingers just experienced the best aromatherapy oils ever.  The pizza bread was fantastically greasy, topped with a generous helping of cheese and very flavorful sausage.  I just got a loaf of sourdough bread.  I don't even eat sourdough bread.  But I figured that since I already made the trek out there, I had to do the right thing and buy their signature bread.

This is one of Chicago's finest Italian bakeries.  There are a couple of locations so the selections can vary from location to location. Here on Grand Avenue youll find breads, foccaio, cookies, and pizza.  If youre planning an entire Italian dinner I suggest a stop next door at Baris Italian grocery.
Its not a bakery you can sit at and enjoy pastries and such but its a great place to get fresh bread to go with your wine or dinner!  They have good pizza too
